The resulting trend towards use of staff members rather than members in situations where police powers are not required increases the likelihood of staff members being the subject of complaints—which would be dealt with in accordance with public service procedures. This bill will provide for members and staff members to be covered in the same complaints regime.

The second major amendment involves the creation of two new offences. The first of these consists of making false statements or giving false information about action taken by an AFP appointee. The corresponding penalty is equivalent to the penalty for misleading the ombudsman under section 44 of the complaints act.

The reason for the creation of this offence is that there have been situations where persons charged with an offence have made extremely serious allegations against innocent appointees in an attempt to draw attention away from themselves or to hinder an investigation. In other cases, people might make false complaints for vindictive or vexatious reasons. This needs to be discouraged, as such complaints have a real impact on the officers concerned, as well as wasting the AFP's limited financial and other resources .

The government is aware that there is some risk inherent in the creation of this offence. Genuine complainants might be deterred through fear of prosecution, or worse, an officer about whom a legitimate complaint has been made might be tempted to retaliate by bringing a charge against the complainant. To prevent this, a charge of making a false complaint will not be able to be made unless the ombudsman has firstly consented to the proceedings. If the ombudsman's consent is not forthcoming, the Attorney-General will ultimately decide whether to bring proceedings. This external control is seen as a safeguard to ensure that the section is not used capriciously against complainants, and to protect the complainant from any possible intimidation.

In addition, a second offence is created whereby anyone who threatens or harms another person because of that person's involvement—or someone else's involvement—in an investigation under the act can be prosecuted for victimisation. It is expected that the simultaneous introduction of these two offences will provide adequate protection for innocent persons while minimising the risk of abuse.

The third major amendment proposed by this bill concerns investigations initiated by the ombudsman of his or her own motion. From time to time the ombudsman will become aware of a matter which could justify a complaint but which has not been the subject of one. Under this act as it stands, the ombudsman has no power to initiate an investigation unless a complaint has been made. This amendment is designed to allow own-motion investigations under the complaints act when they are necessary.

A fourth significant change, which entails a number of minor amendments, relates to the admissibility of evidence obtained by the ombudsman. At present, such evidence is not admissible in disciplinary proceedings. Although this is consistent with the ombudsman's wider role, it is inconsistent with the role of independent investigator which the ombudsman fills under the complaints act, and will bring the ombudsman's provisions into line with the admissibility of evidence obtained by the internal investigation division of the AFP. Investigation by the ombudsman under the act is a last resort and if it is to have real credibility it is necessary that the evidence obtained in the course of such investigations be made admissible.

The final major amendment focuses on the procedure for the hearing of minor disciplinary charges to which an officer charged pleads guilty. At present, a member who recognises that he or she has made a relatively minor mistake may be subjected to the penalty of prolonged uncertainty, because often the disciplinary tribunal will not be convened until a more serious case arises. The proposed amendment allows such cases to be dealt with by the commissioner, where the ombudsman agrees, instead of the tribunal. It is designed to eliminate unnecessary delays under the present procedure while providing guarantees that the procedure adopted does not improperly protect the police. The matter can be referred to the tribunal for penalty by the commissioner if the ombudsman agrees.

This opportunity has also been taken to make a number of minor amendments, including changes to the conciliation procedure to reflect the consolidation of ranks in the AFP, extension of the ombudsman's discretion not to investigate trivial complaints to ensure that limited resources are concentrated on more serious matters, and the removal of sexist terminology in those parts of the act where gender neutral language has not already been introduced. Other small adjustments are designed simply to replace procedures which have turned out to be practically inconvenient with more efficient methods.

It is hoped that the amendments contained in this bill will bring about a significant improvement in the day-to-day operation of the complaints act while removing or replacing those provisions which, because of changes in the structure of the AFP work force over the past decade, no longer have a policy basis. The bill demonstrates the government's continuing commitment to the implementation, wherever possible, of recommendations made by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and more generally to ensuring the accountability of public officials, including the police.
The amendments have no financial impact. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first address in this chamber, Mr Deputy Speaker, and, having been a policeman for nine years, I have some sympathy with the role of police officers in the increasingly complex and difficult milieu in which they work. Of course, one can refer back to Gilbert and Sullivan's famous light opera the Pirates of Penzance for the famous line `A policeman's lot is not a happy one, happy one.'

PARA.TAB: The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill comes some considerable length after the initial requests. The amendments come from the working group which was put together back in 1989 and, at the request of the Australian Federal Police Association, which had made a number of representations to the then Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, the working group proposed a number of amendments to the principal act. In December 1990, the minister wrote to the AFPA indicating that a number of its proposals, together with the other suggested amendments to the principal act, would be considered in a general review of the principal act which should have been completed during 1991.

This review, which commenced in 1991 in May and reported in October 1991, included in the working group representatives of the Attorney-General's Department, the AFP, the AFPA, the ombudsman's office and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. A number of proposals were recommended by the working group and, of course, they found their way eventually into this legislation.

The coalition has some concerns in relation to the bill. One of those concerns is the manner in which the review of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 has been undertaken since its inception. As I mentioned, these current amendments being implemented stem from a request of the Australian Federal Police Association made in April 1989. A working party review was not commenced until 1991, after it was indicated that the AFPA concerns would be addressed as part of the review of the act as a whole. Now, more than five years after the original request made by the AFPA, the government has finally introduced its legislation, and this seems an extraordinary delay indeed.

Now we have been informed by the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) that he has approved another wholesale review of the act. We can only infer that the initial review took so long to implement that its results are now out of date before they have even been implemented. This situation is obviously less acceptable for the Australian Federal Police officers who are governed by this act, employees and members of the public who are also affected by the legislation.

The coalition has supported the bill in the Senate, but it had it referred the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. This was done because of the following concerns raised by the Law Council of Australia. Firstly, the Law Council of Australia agreed that evidence taken before an ombudsman should be admissible but that there should also be a corresponding obligation on the prosecution of disclosure of such material in any event.

Further to that particular comment, there should be a converse rule that the complaint and any statement made by the complainant be privileged from production in proceedings relating to separate criminal charges against the complainant, except clause 6, which relates to false complaints. Otherwise there would be a severe disincentive from making complaints against police.

Thirdly, in relation to clause 6, which creates the new offence of making a false complaint or giving false information, the suggestion is made that there be a requirement, before a conviction can be sustained, that the charge should be corroborated. The Law Council suggested that this would be no different from a charge of perjury, which requires corroboration and for which the policy consideration justifying the requirement of independent confirmation is the same.

Some concern was expressed about the ability of the Australian Federal Police to launch prosecutions under clause 6. Even though they are apparently required to consult the ombudsman in respect of such prosecutions, there is no obligation to take the advice given. The Law Council believes that before a prosecution can be launched it should positively require the consent of the ombudsman and it should be independently prosecuted by the Director of Public Prosecutions. In the committee report, the coalition, by a dissenting report, recommended that clause 6 be reviewed so that, should the ombudsman object to any prosecution for false complaint or for providing false information in relation to a complaint, the matter can be referred to the Attorney-General.

As I said earlier, apart from that particular point, the coalition supports the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill and acknowledges the purpose for which these particular amendments were constructed. This was obviously to eliminate anomalies and to meet practical concerns arising out of operations of the act since its commencement and the introduction of the new AFP rank structure.

The major amendments, as has been noted by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), are to extend its coverage to include non-sworn AFP staff, whose exclusion from the complaints act regime is no longer justified by differential allocation of duties to members and staff members under clause 2 definitions, and we certainly have no problem with that particular change. It also creates two new offences, making a false complaint or giving false information—clause 6 and section 19—and victimisation of a complainant or a person assisting in the investigation of a complaint.

The parliamentary secretary in his address acknowledged that in this modern era of police investigations, particularly in relation to the complex and often very serious criminal matters that are investigated by the Australian Federal Police, there are naturally going to be times when a suspect or an accused person is going to be trying very hard to use the complaints system to either delay or impede an investigation which could well result in a conviction. We have seen in recent times a burgeoning of complaints in relation to the operations of police investigations, and these have, I think, been somewhat encouraged to a certain extent by some of the judiciary. That has meant that, for instance, people who have very serious charges levelled against them have been able to delay and slow down the prosecution process accordingly, and that has made things difficult in relation to the marshalling of witnesses in a particular case. One of the most difficult jobs for an AFP investigator, or any other police investigator, for that matter, is to ensure that the witnesses are marshalled for the case when it is eventually prosecuted in court.

In cases where one has serious drug offences which may involve hundreds of thousands of dollars in potential proceeds for the criminals, that means that witnesses, particularly if they come from the drug trafficking milieu, are likely to feel somewhat intimidated by the length of time it takes to get to a prosecution. If a smart criminal or person who has been accused has some aptitude for creating the circumstances for a complaint, that may slow down an investigation or make it more difficult for the AFP investigators to be able to retain that witness's potential participation in the case. It may impede the eventual conviction or the objective of eventually convicting the offenders.

The third change is to provide for investigation by the ombudsman's own motion of action by a member or staff member of the AFP. The fourth change is to make evidence obtained by the ombudsman in the course of investigation admissible in disciplinary hearings—clause 11, amending existing section 27—and to abolish the requirement that hearings of complaint-raised disciplinary charges be held before the disciplinary tribunal where the appointee charged pleads guilty. The option of a tribunal hearing where the public interest requires it is actually retained—clause 16, new part VA, section 52A.

There are minor amendments to the changes to the rank requirements for conciliators in complaint cases—clause 3, conciliation. We certainly do not have any problems with that. There is an extension of the ombudsman's discretion to determine that a complaint should not be investigated where he or she is satisfied that it is trivial—clause 9 amending existing section 24. There are adjustments to penalty provisions to bring them into line with current policy so that monetary and time penalties are changed to unit penalties—schedule 3—and the removal of sexist terminology which is a process that is being undertaken in many parts of our Commonwealth legislation, even, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you well know, in our own standing orders. That has been something that has been recently—

TALK.START.PARA: —Political correctness.
—More correct language that appears to be more acceptable has been implemented, even in the case of standing orders.

PARA.TAB: The police ministers of South Australia, Tasmania, New South Wales and the Northern Territory see no significant differences in the treatment of complaints against the AFP, if this bill is passed, and their own state complaints procedures. I understand the AFPA, which was involved with the interdepartmental working group, agrees with the amendments. I have already raised the concerns the coalition had that were raised by the Law Council of Australia. I will not go into further detail. Of course, we have heard from the parliamentary secretary that there is no financial impact.

At this stage, we have had the matter referred back from the Senate committee with a committee report with a dissenting report recommending that clause 6 be reviewed so that, should the ombudsman object to any prosecution for false complaint or for providing false information in relation to complaint, the matter should then be referred to the Attorney-General. I suppose this comes at a difficult time in relation to Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements. Those who have an interest in that area would obviously have been following with some interest the actions of the federal government after the Report of the review of Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements. Those are going to amount to some very significant changes in relation to the role of the Australian Federal Police and the NCA.
Before I go into that Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements review report, I will look at the mission function that is stated in it for the Australian Federal Police. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Federal Police . . . was established by the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 . . . which was proclaimed on 19 October 1979. Section 8 of that Act provides for the AFP to perform the following functions:
.the provision of police services in relation to the Australian Capital Territory under arrangements with the ACT Government;
.the provision of police services in relation to the Jervis Bay Territory;
.the provision of police services in relation to:
-laws of the Commonwealth;
-property of the Commonwealth (including Commonwealth places) and property of authorities of the Commonwealth; and
-the safeguarding of the Commonwealth interest;
.the provision of police and regulatory services in relation to External Territories (of Christmas, Cocos (Keeling) and Norfolk Islands) under arrangements with the External Territories;
.the provision of witness protection services for State/Territory police forces, the NCA and prescribed Commonwealth/State/Territory authorities; and
.anything incidental or conducive to the performance of the foregoing functions.
The report continues:

PARA.TAB: Under section 13(2) of the AFP Act, the Minister for Justice may give written directions to the Commissioner with respect to the general policy to be pursued in relation to the performance of the functions of the AFP. The Minister last issued such a Direction on 4 December 1991. The AFP's operational priorities, based on the guidance in the Direction, are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .Provide the best in prevention, detection and investigation of criminal offences against the laws of the Commonwealth, with emphasis on:
-providing effective strategic intelligence on criminal matters;
-attacking the financial base of criminal activity; and
-assisting in the maintenance of the integrity of financial institutions and their trading activities;
.Provide a high quality community policing service for the ACT;
.Enhance the AFP's capability to support its diverse international obligations; and
.Provide leadership in the Australian law enforcement effort and assistance to all areas of Commonwealth administration.

One of the key recommendations of this particular report, something to which these amendments to the act are going to have some relevance, is the change to the staffing resources of the NCA and the proposed strategic alliance between the NCA and the AFP. Under the section relating to the National Crime Authority, at paragraph 18.26, the review report says:

In Chapter 7 of the Report the Review recommends the retention of the NCA as a stand-alone strategic and co-ordinating body of State and Commonwealth agencies, to regulate, deter and bring to justice those engaged in organised crime. The Review argues that the NCA, appropriately tasked and resourced, is in the best position to achieve these aims.
In paragraph 18.27, it then says:
In addition, the Review recommends the following changes to the NCA:
.Expansion of projects being undertaken by the NCA to those listed in Chapter 7.

There is a menu of particular investigative targets or objects that would be set and reviewed by the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board, the new agency or the new board that has been recommended to be set up as a result of this review report.
The report continues:
.Consideration be given to legislatively confining the NCA to the type of role defined in Chapter 7.

.Formation of a strategic alliance between the NCA and the AFP. A high proportion of NCA investigators should be officers of the AFP and technical and other services of the two organisations should be integrated as far as possible. It is anticipated that savings of $7-8m per annum can be achieved through integration of AFP and NCA corporate support, Police Technical Unit-type functions, and information technology.

.Implementation of the Review's suggested staff and resource structure for the NCA . . . The Review recommends that the Government request the NCA Chairperson to indicate within three months the staff changes and savings which might accrue as a result of these recommendations . . . The Review also recommends that the NCA be required to proceed in the direction of these recommendations, which include negotiation of an arrangement with the AFP for appropriate officers of the NCA to become members of the AFP and for the investigative resources of the NCA to come from the AFP in the future (except for those which come from relevant State police forces). The recommendations also provide for adjustments to the other staff of the NCA for future needs as defined in the recommendations. The issue of NCA Cost Sharing is dealt with in Chapter 16.

When the working group was looking at the minor amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act, this was not envisaged. The fact that there will be collocation, and the fact that NCA officers will become sworn AFP officers in certain circumstances, gives a different spin to the changes that are being proposed by the government in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, it was certainly not envisaged at the time when the working group was formulating this report that the NCA would be collocated or have a strategic alliance with the NCA. So there is some concern. I am echoing the concerns that have been registered by senior staff members and other staff members of the NCA. Certainly, as a former investigator, I also have some concerns about whether this particular legislation might impede NCA investigations.

For instance, there might be the situation where a person with a smart brief might well decide that in order to impede what may be a very high level NCA investigative effort, he will start making complaints against NCA and AFP officers who are both, presumably, governed by the AFP Act. The actual arrangements, I understand, have yet to be finally thrashed out. This is a tumultuous period for members of the AFP and also for the personnel of the NCA because there is still a fair amount of instability and insecurity.

Some of these concerns were registered at the public hearing of the NCA joint statutory committee—the parliamentary joint committee of which I am a member—a couple of weeks ago. Very serious concern was expressed about the morale of the NCA personnel because of these changes. In particular, there were very serious concerns about the continuing independence of the NCA. As a member of the PJC, I am very concerned about that. One of the things that was integral to the creation of the NCA was the fact that it would be an independent body that would essentially be acting upon the references given to it by the intergovernmental committee, which consists of attorneys-general, justice ministers or police ministers from the various states, and the federal justice minister and the federal Attorney-General.

There has been a tilting away from what I consider to be the best role for the National Crime Authority as an independent body with references given to it by the intergovernmental committee to its role as a body that is now going to have collocated AFP personnel and, of course, information sharing. NCA officers will now be sworn AFP officers and, under certain circumstances, will be governed by the amendments that are being made to the act. There are also the concerns of the staff of the NCA, as I have already mentioned, about the future integrity and independence of the NCA's investigative efforts.

Because of the change in emphasis from the intergovernmental committee to the CLEB, the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board, there will be some changes to the nature of the investigation of objects or targets. We have already seen in the report a list of various organised criminal objects or targets, amongst which are the Yakuza gangs, outlawed motorcycle gangs, paedophile networks and the like. Essentially, these lists would be determined or adjusted or updated by the CLEB.

Also involved in that, and this is a difficult matter, is the fact that the chairperson of the NCA, Mr Sherman, also chairs the CLEB. In my view, there is a potential there for a conflict of interest between his role as the chairperson of the NCA, the first officer of the NCA, and his role as the Chairman of the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board, which has a distinctly different role from that of the National Crime Authority. The independence of the NCA, and its separation from the AFP, something that I think we should have maintained, will be of more concern in the future. As I have indicated, we have already had registered with us, by senior members of the staff, very serious concerns as to the future of the style of the NCA and the type of investigations it does.

I am someone who believes that the value of the NCA was enhanced by the fact that it was created not only in Commonwealth law but also in the various state statutes, which enables there to be an NCA within each state. I think the changes are a matter of concern to those of us who believed in the arrangements with the intergovernmental committee, even though they were not perfect and from time to time certainly did not work particularly well. It seems strange that the federal Labor government, marooned in a sea of Liberal state governments, wants to change away from what was seen to be a reasonable arrangement, and one that allowed for a fair amount of involvement on the part of the states.

There have been some criticisms that because the AFP is subject to much more direction from the ministerial level than the NCA—the NCA has an independence—and because of involvement in the strategic alliance, the collocation and the co-staffing, the NCA's independence may well be infringed through the ability of the minister to be able to issue directives, et cetera. The NCA's independence could also be infringed through what I consider to be a potential conflict of interest with this matter of the chairperson of the NCA also being the chairperson of the CLEB.

In the concluding part of my address I come to a matter that is of concern in my electorate. I would hate to be parochial, but it was mentioned in the explanatory memorandum that the Australian Federal Police has a much more substantial or increasing role in detecting frauds against the Commonwealth, particularly in areas where welfare payments or social security payments are at stake. That starts to involve the AFP in areas that are much greyer than, say, the more open-and-shut criminal cases of people trafficking in drugs, importing drugs or whatever. It certainly means that there are going to be some serious situations for AFP investigative officers and, in particular, for those people who are subjected to investigations through no fault of their own.

A strawberry grower in my electorate was visited—I suppose I could say euphemistically that he received a visit, but in fact it was a raid—by the Australian Federal Police and by Australian Taxation Office personnel on 27 November 1991, between 4.30 and 5.30 in the morning, at the height of the strawberry growing season. Approximately 25 officers of the ATO and the AFP raided properties in Carabooda, in my electorate. For those who are not familiar with that area, it is one where there has been a very important niche market for export strawberries. We have a $5 million export market from the area. The difficulty is that growing strawberries and other fruit and vegetables involves seasonal labour. This is the rub for employers who are trying to do the right thing.

People employed in the seasonal vegetable and fruit industry come, in some cases, from South-East Asian backgrounds. The reason is often that they have experience from their previous homeland in fruit and vegetable growing activities. They have a natural affinity for it. In many cases they work for a period of time, set themselves up on their own farm and then become successful fruit and vegetable growers in their own right. In my area we have had some examples of very successful growers who have come to the country virtually penniless, worked hard and then managed to create the circumstances in which they can establish their own farm.

In this instance, the difficulty arises for an employer trying to do the right thing. We should bear in mind the requirements of the statutes, including the tax act, and requirements in employer declarations and the like. Under the tax file number system there are certain privacy requirements, and there is a 28-day period in which an employee can lodge the form.

In this case, the Australian Federal Police, acting as far as we can see quite lawfully and obviously pursuing inquiries that had been referred to them by the Australian Taxation Office, executed search warrants on my constituent's farm at the height of the strawberry season. I note that a bill to be debated later talks about cultural influence. Because of some cultural differences on the part of some of the casual workers, after the raid the majority of them left the property and would not return. In fact, on 28 November, the next day, only a handful returned to work. On 29 and 30 November, none of them returned to work. As a result of the shortage in labour, approximately 70 per cent of my constituent's strawberry crop could not be picked. The fruit overripened and became unmarketable.

As a result of the raid on the farm, nine casual workers were charged and convicted of 12 offences under the Taxation Administration Act. Again I am not suggesting that somehow this was unlawful or unwarranted. The difficulty occurs where somebody is conducting a lawful business but something has given rise to a suspicion that people there may be defrauding the Commonwealth or involved in offences which amount to the same thing, and where the Australian Federal Police feel obliged to use search warrants and a raid to obtain evidence. As a result of this, the person conducting that lawful business may suddenly find himself or herself considerably out of pocket. The difficulty is that there is little or nothing the person can do about it, so long as that warrant is right. I see my learned colleague opposite, the Member for Banks (Mr Melham), nodding.

As a man who has spent some time as a public defender, he would know—as I would know, as a former detective—that, if the warrant is lawful, there is really precious little people can do about the fact that it may well have interfered substantially with their day-to-day trade. That is a difficulty.

That is why I am saying that, as the involvement of the AFP evolves more substantially into these more grey areas—where one is dealing with frauds against the Commonwealth, some of which may involve, in the case of employers, things which are, because of other constraints and legislation, quite difficult to actually detect on the part of the employer—people have a problem in that they have really got nowhere they can go.

That is why I would like to alert the minister—perhaps the acting parliamentary secretary opposite can alert him—to the fact that there ought to be a review, or perhaps an inquiry, into the way in which citizens can redress problems such as those created by the raids that were undertaken in Carabooda in 1991 on my constituent's farm, as a result of which he lost about $1 1/2 million worth of strawberry crop. The person who, in fact, alerted the community to these particular problems with casual labour—in public, in the newspapers—became subject to the raid himself, lost a considerable amount of money and has nowhere he can go.

On that note, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will conclude. Other than those changes that were proposed by the Law Council, the coalition supports the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite often, I think, the Australian community looks at members of parliament and at the shambles that question time often appears to be, and considers that, in all matters, we tend to be confrontationist, and that, on both sides of politics, we are very often simply unable to agree. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendments Bill 1994 is one of those very many cases in which it is pretty clear that this parliament works.

PARA.TAB: The bill was introduced, by the government, into the Senate, and there was a debate there. There were some suggested amendments, and there was some consultation with the community. The bill was referred to a Senate committee, which brought down a report and a minority report which, basically, made certain suggestions as to how the bill could be improved.

The government has picked up some of those suggestions, with the result that we now have an amended bill before the Committee. If it is carried in this place and in the other place, we certainly will find that the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill 1994, when it becomes law, will be a very much better piece of legislation than it would have been had it not gone through the processes that I have outlined.

Really, the very large majority of pieces of legislation passing through the parliament does so with the consent of both sides. Of course, there are some bills and some major national issues about which we, on this side of the House, take issue with the government. But we aim to be a constructive opposition in this place, and not simply to oppose every proposal brought forward by the government.

At this stage, I might stress that we do not hesitate to oppose the government when the government is proposing something which we believe is disastrous. I must say that 11 years of Labor government have, indeed, been very disastrous for the nation, in many ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—I am pleased that my colleague, the honourable member for Banks, obviously agrees with me.
—You're verballing my laughter.

—I hope that the honourable member is not suggesting that I have verballed him. The coalition, when it first received the bill before the Committee at the moment, consulted widely with the Australian community, as is usual. As my honourable colleague the member for Moore (Mr Filing) said, the federal government is now marooned in a sea of hostile state governments. I suppose I would say that the government was all at sea. It is now very easy for us to consult with our various state police ministers, because most of them are on side.
—We have the one who counts, though.
—The government might well have the one who counts at the moment, but, clearly, after the next election he will drown with the rest of the government.

PARA.TAB: The coalition also consulted the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Federal Police Association. The bill amends the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, an act which governs the handling of complaints made, whether by members of the public or by Australian Federal Police members, against the Australian Federal Police and its members, including disciplinary measures consequent on a complaint and all disciplinary appeals.

In the Australia of 1994, where there is a very great desire to make sure that agencies of government are accountable, it is clearly important that proper procedures are in place so that one is able to make a complaint against an officer of the police force, or an officer of some other government agency, who breaches the regulations on procedures. The history of royal commissions and inquiries, not only in the Commonwealth sphere, but also in the state sphere over the last 10 years, shows that it is very important to make sure that we have that accountability. It is also very important to seek the right sort of balance. If we come down too heavily against the police, we will find that the police will not be able to do their duty, and, if we do not have adequate procedures which will enable genuine complaints to be investigated, the public will lose confidence, not only in the administration of the police services, but in the administration of justice

In Queensland there is a problem. We have a situation where, when police receive complaints, in many cases they are frightened to carry out their duty, because, if they approach a person who is suspected of being an offender, that person will immediately threaten them with the Criminal Justice Commission. We have had instances where police officers who were simply trying to do their job, trying to protect society, have, in effect, been turned into the criminals. They have been dragged down before a committee of three police inspectors and shoved in front of a video camera. Quite often, therefore, police are saying that, unless it is a very serious complaint, it is simply not worth the hassle. If young people get drunk in the main streets of some towns or cities, if there is obscene language here and there, or if a bit too much noise is being made, it is now very difficult in Queensland to get the police service to go out and investigate those complaints, because police are simply not prepared to have their reputations and careers destroyed, or placed in doubt, as a result of a spurious complaint to the CJC.

That is one matter that the Queensland government is going to have to look at. Under this legislation we are trying to bring forward a fair, reasonable and balanced procedure to make sure that, on the one hand, complaints against the federal police are investigated appropriately, but, on the other hand, police are still able to carry out the very important duty that they do for the people of Australia.

The amendments arise out of the report of an interdepartmental working group, which was established in mid-1991. This group was comprised of representatives of the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian Federal Police. In consultation with the Australian Federal Police Association, the working group considered proposals by all interested parties, as well as the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the review of the ombudsman's office by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

The government has introduced the amendments now before the committee in order to eliminate anomalies and to meet practical concerns arising out of the operation of the act since its commencement and the introduction of the new Australian Federal Police rank structure. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) has pointed out, there are a number of amendments to the legislation, both major and minor. The major amendments are to extend the act's coverage to include non-sworn AFP staff, whose exclusion from the complaints regime is no longer justified by differential allocation of duties to members and staff members. This is contained in the definition section, clause 2.

In the federal area, as indeed in state police services, over the years we have had two groups of people working on behalf of the community. On the one hand, we have sworn police officers; on the other, we have had public servants. I suppose there has been a tendency by governments on both sides of the political spectrum to involve public servants more and more in performing roles which do not require the use of police powers. So if we look at the duties carried out by Public Service members today, many of these would be duties which 10 or 20 years ago would have been the prerogative of sworn police officers.

The natural result of this is that the kinds of complaints that used to arise against police officers when carrying out those duties are indeed now sheeted home to these members of the Public Service. The government has quite accurately identified the need to ensure that complaints procedures against public servants who are carrying out duties which traditionally have been police duties are the same procedures in essence as those which would be followed if a police officer were carrying out the duties and had done what was complained of. The bill also seeks to create two new offences: making a false complaint or giving false information—clause 6, proposed new section 19; and victimisation of a complainant or a person assisting in the investigation of a complaint—clause 19, proposed new section 88A.

The amendments also provide for investigations by the ombudsman's own motion—very important, in my view—of action by a member of, or staff member of, the AFP—clause 7, proposed new section 21A. The amendments also are to make evidence obtained by the ombudsman in the course of an investigation admissible in disciplinary hearings—clause 11, amending existing section 27—and to abolish the requirement that hearings of complaint based disciplinary charges be held before the disciplinary tribunal where the appointee charged pleads guilty. Most importantly, the option of a tribunal hearing where the public interest requires it is retained—clause 16, proposed new part 5A, section 52A.

In addition to these major amendments to the legislation, there are, as I said before, a number of minor amendments. These relate to changes to the rank requirements for conciliators in complaint cases—clause 3, conciliation—an extension of the ombudsman's discretion to determine that a complaint should not be investigated where he or she is satisfied that it is trivial—clause 9 amending section 24. I think this is important because quite often one finds that people might bring forward a complaint which is obviously not a complaint of substance but the person bringing forward the complaint might be someone who is facing very serious charges, and what this person might be seeking to do is to bring in procedural inhibitions to the law carrying out its usual pursuit of the conduct for which the person is being charged. The last thing that anyone in this place would want would be for a person to be able to use technicalities to impede the prosecution of justice.

Amongst the minor amendments also are adjustments to penalty provisions to bring them into line with current policy so that monetary and time penalties are changed to unit penalties—schedule 3. Of course, as we have inflation over the years—and under this Labor government we have had very high inflation for a very large number of years—quite often the penalties under legislation appear to be quite trivial. In a lot of the criminal codes, admittedly state legislation, one finds that a person could well be fined the sum of #1. At the time that these criminal codes were enacted, #1 was a very large amount of money, but today $2 seems to disappear whenever one passes a cash register.

The legislation also seeks to remove so-called sexist terminology. The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) would be aware that this is one of my hobbyhorses, that I get concerned about the political correctness that has now been set loose in our society. I think that, sadly, a lot of the terms which have been used in legislation like the legislation we are discussing, and indeed throughout society, may have been deemed to be sexist. But, when one looks at the Latin origins of the particular terminology, really the language and the terms are in fact not sexist at all. I refer to the word `chairman'. Before the committee of the whole was scrapped, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you were the Chairman of Committees and you had a guiding hand.

Of course, the Latin derivation of the word `chairman' does not relate to the fact that you are obviously a male person. But the thought police have been set loose and many whom some would describe as feminazis have said that the term `chairman' is relating to the male. However, when one looks at the Latin derivation of the term there is nothing sexist about it at all. Now we find that the term `chairperson' has been adopted regularly.

That is probably a battle that has been long lost. I am not terribly offended by some of these changes that have been made but I do think it is going over the top on many occasions. Really what we ought to do is to rejoice in our English language, which is a language we have had for a very long time. I think that it is sad that we are tending to distort and change this language simply to attend to the sensibilities of an interest group. There is no doubt that some terms could be changed and should be changed, but I think that far too many have been and that in doing so what we are doing is looking at the perceptions of the language rather than the origins of the particular terms which have been found to be offensive.

The police ministers of South Australia, Tasmania, New South Wales and the Northern Territory see no significant differences between the treatment of complaints against the Australian Federal Police if this bill is passed and their own state complaints procedures. The Australian Federal Police Association, which was involved with the interdepartmental working group, now agrees with the amendments.

The Law Council of Australia has raised some points in relation to the amendments. It agrees that evidence taken before an ombudsman should be admissible but that there should also be a corresponding obligation on the prosecution of disclosure of such material in any event. Further to the above comment, there should be a converse rule that the complaint and any statement made by the complainant be privileged from production in proceedings relating to separate criminal charges against the complainant, except clause 6, which relates to false complaints. Otherwise there would be a severe disincentive for making complaints against police.

In relation to clause 6, which creates the new offence of making a false complaint or giving false information, the suggestion is made that there should be a requirement that before a conviction can be sustained the charge should be corroborated. The Law Council suggests that this would be no different from a charge of perjury, which requires corroboration and for which the policy consideration justifying the requirement of independent confirmation is the same.

Some concern was expressed about the ability of the Australian Federal Police to launch prosecutions under clause 6. Even though they are apparently required to consult the ombudsman with respect to such prosecutions, there is no obligation to take the advice given. The Law Council believed that before a prosecution could be launched it should positively require the consent of the ombudsman and it should be independently prosecuted by the Director of Public Prosecutions.

As I said before, this bill was referred to a Senate standing committee and a report was handed down. Indeed, there was a dissenting report from the coalition in which we recommended that clause 6 be reviewed so that, should the ombudsman object to any prosecution for false complaint or for providing false information in relation to a complaint, the matter would then be referred to the Attorney-General. As I have said earlier, the government has picked up the substance of this dissenting report, with the result that in the Senate an amendment was moved and passed which incorporated what we said in our dissenting report on the bill now before the Committee.

In the short amount of time remaining to me I would like to express some concern over the manner in which the review of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 has been undertaken since its inception. This piece of legislation became law in 1981, which, if my calculations are correct, was 13 years ago. The current amendments being implemented stem from a request from the Australian Federal Police Association made in April 1989. That is more than five years ago. A working party review was not commenced until 1991, which was two years after the request was made. This appears to me to be an extraordinary delay. I really do not know why such a delay has been allowed to occur.

More than five years after the original request was made by the Australian Federal Police Association, we finally have legislation which we are debating. I suppose one could say it is better late than never. I really would be interested to know from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General why there has been such an incredible delay. If we are going to take five years from the time a request is made that legislation should be looked at until we find amending legislation brought into the parliament, then quite often that amending legislation could be rendered totally irrelevant by the effluxion of time before we in fact debate it.

That is obviously what has happened in this particular case, because the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has now approved another wholesale review of the act. We can only infer that the initial review took so long to implement that its results were out of date before they could even be implemented. We are now debating a bill which the government knows, almost by its own admission, is outdated. The Minister for Justice is conducting a further review, which presumably will review the review which has indeed resulted in the bill now before the chamber.

Most reasonable Australians would accept that five years between a request for a review and the proposal of legislation is unacceptable, as is the fact that no sooner do we see this legislation than the minister says that we are going to have yet another review. The Australian Federal Police deserves better, and I hope that the government takes this on board. I would be very interested indeed to hear the explanation from the parliamentary secretary, in due course, as to why the government has taken five years from the request until we see this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to offer some comments which are very similar to those offered by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), who has asked a couple of pertinent questions. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act was passed in 1981, creating a complaints regime in broad conformity with the recommendations of two Australian Law Reform Commission reports on complaints against police. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill is the first substantial proposed revision of the complaints regime governing the AFP. It arises out of the review mentioned by the member for Fisher of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 by an interdepartmental working group set up by the then Minister for Justice, former Senator the Hon. Michael Tate, in response to representations made by the Australian Federal Police Association as long ago as April 1989.

PARA.TAB: The working group had the benefit at that time of contributions by the Attorney-General's Department, the AFP, the ombudsman's office, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the AFP Association. The working group considered proposals by all interested parties, as well as reports of both the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration's review of the ombudsman's office, and presented its report in October 1991—more than three years ago.

Finally, on 30 June this year, the government introduced legislation to deal with the recommendations of the working group and the concerns of the AFP Association. As the member for Fisher pointed out, this legislation comes some five years after the original request was made by the AFP Association. The Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) told the Senate committee that examined this bill that he has now approved another wholesale review of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act. One has to query whether another such review should be necessary when this bill has not even been enacted.

If a fresh review is necessary because the government has dragged its feet in implementing the results of the working group's review, then the situation is of some concern. Justice delayed is justice denied and, for similar reasons, it might be suggested that law reform delayed is law reform denied, or is no law reform at all. The situation of AFP officers, other employees of the AFP and members of the public who are affected by this legislation is cause for concern in these circumstances.

The coalition supports the general thrust of the bill and, in the Senate, has been able to ensure that proper amendments have been made. The bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in August 1994 and the committee reported in the following month.

In relation to complaint handling procedures, the bill is aimed at addressing two important issues. The first concerns the general trend towards external review. This involves the introduction of substantive non-police involvement in the complaints regime. The reason for this is the need for an effective monitoring system and, at the same time, a strengthening of public confidence in the complaints-handling process. The external role is filled by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The bill strengthens the ombudsman's role by giving her the power to investigate matters of her own motion.

The second issue is keeping a balance between ensuring that police have appropriate power to investigate criminal conduct on the one hand, and preserving the liberties, rights and privacy of individual citizens on the other hand. To this end, the bill creates the new offence of making a false complaint about the actions of an AFP appointee. The provisions creating this new offence were the focus of some attention and concern in the Senate and before the Senate committee.

Briefly, the main objectives of the bill are fivefold. Firstly, there is provision for the extension of the act to include non-sworn AFP staff. Secondly, three new offences are created, namely, knowingly making a false complaint, knowingly giving false information about a complaint and victimising a complainant or a person who has given information in relation to a complaint. Thirdly, the bill proposes to enable the ombudsman to investigate actions of an AFP appointee on his or her—in this case, on her—own motion. Fourthly, the bill will make evidence obtained by the ombudsman in the course of an investigation admissible in disciplinary proceedings. Finally, the bill will allow complaint based disciplinary charges to be dealt with internally by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police where the AFP appointee who is charged pleads guilty. The option of the disciplinary tribunal's hearing the matter is retained where the public interest justifies it.

The Law Council of Australia initially raised the concerns of the coalition that prompted referral of this bill to the Senate committee. The concerns included the question of whether before a conviction for making a false complaint can be sustained the evidence should be corroborated, as is required with a charge of perjury. Another concern was whether the consent of the ombudsman should be a precondition to a prosecution for making a false complaint rather than the lesser requirement that the ombudsman be consulted.

Turning to the false complaint offence provisions, the bill provides that it is an offence if a person makes a complaint and knows that the complaint is false in a material particular and if a person supplies information to an AFP appointee in relation to a complaint that the person knows to be false in a material particular. The maximum fine is $2,000. These provisions criminalise the making of knowingly false complaints generally but have a particular relevance to non-AFP members who are not already covered by the principal act in relation to false complaints. The policy reason for this offence is the belief that deliberately false and serious allegations of misconduct are directed at AFP members as a common tactic by persons under investigation in order to throw the police off their investigation.

As a result of the proceedings before the Senate committee, the Minister for Justice agreed to move an amendment to the false complaint provisions in order to change the requirement of consultation with the ombudsman to a requirement that the ombudsman consent to any prosecution. If the ombudsman did not agree with the decision to charge an individual, then the ultimate decision would be made by the Attorney-General.

The majority report by the committee recommended that the bill, with the amendment proposed by the Minister for Justice, be passed. In referring to it as a majority report, I would point out that it was supported by the four government members of the eight person committee. The Democrat member, Senator Spindler, and the opposition members delivered two dissenting reports.

Senator Spindler wanted to move his own amendment to the consultation or consent requirement. He felt that non-police corroboration was necessary for the prosecution of a false complaint and he wanted a general privilege for information made by a complainant in the complaint to the ombudsman to preclude that information being used in subsequent criminal proceedings.

The coalition report accepted that, on the issue of corroboration, a charge of false complaint was relevantly different from a charge of perjury and that corroboration should not, therefore, be a requirement.

In relation to the question of consent or consultation, the coalition members' dissenting report recommended that the bill, in its then form, be amended to include the requirement that the ombudsman give his or her imprimatur before any prosecution proceed. If the ombudsman declined to approve a prosecution for false complaint, the matter should then be referred to the Attorney-General.

As a result of the committee's reports, the bill was duly amended in the Senate to replace the consultation requirement in the false complaint provisions with a requirement for the consent of the ombudsman. In its amended form, the bill is supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will respond very briefly. There were a number of useful points made by opposition spokespersons and I take those on board. As has been pointed out, the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Amendment Bill has been, in fact, finetuned in the Senate and I am happy to welcome the changes that were made.

PARA.TAB: The only comment I want to make of any substance is to respond to the criticism that has been made, firstly, of the time that it took from the moment that the AFP Association raised issues of concern and sought action from the government and, secondly, the fact that the government has now announced a further and, this time, wide ranging review. I would simply make the point that, from the time that the AFP Association sought changes to this legislation, its request, in fact, was not for a wide ranging review of the legislation but for specific amendments that it proposed.

The government, having considered those amendments, initially set up the working party that has been referred to by honourable members. The working party, in the fullness of time, reported, and the government subsequently went through the processes of having legislation prepared for cabinet approval, the drafting of the legislation and finally the introduction the legislation to the House. All of these things are inevitably matters for priorities and, as such, the government gave this the highest priority that it could in the circumstances.

As to the new review arising out of the work that has been done on the proposals for amendments that came from the Australian Federal Police Association, the government recognised the fact that this legislation did require a wholesale review and that is what has been now set in train. The legislation in total will be put under scrutiny and, in addition to that, any proposals for changes in the fundamental way that complaints against the AFP are dealt with will be looked at in that review. That is the purpose and reason for that, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Duncan)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 7 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes amendments to a number of acts dealing with Commonwealth criminal law or law enforcement matters. As a number of the amendments are technical in nature, I propose to discuss only the substantive amendments made by this bill.

PARA.TAB: Three amendments to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 will:

SPEECH.PARA: .include certain offences created by the Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Act 1992 within the category of politically motivated violence under the ASIO Act;

.allow the Director-General of Security to give a standing authorisation to senior officers of ASIO to approve persons who are to be able to exercise the authority of warrants issued by the Attorney-General; and
.allow officers of ASIO to apply for vacant positions in the Australian Public Service even though the positions have not been advertised as being open to the public.

The offences from the Ships and Fixed Platforms Act which will be included in the definition of `politically motivated violence' in the ASIO Act are similar to those which are already specified in that act. They are of a type often associated with terrorist activities. Accordingly, it is appropriate to include these offences as acts of politically motivated violence against which it is ASIO's function to protect Australia and Australians.

PARA.TAB: Part III of the ASIO Act permits ASIO, under the authority of a warrant issued by the Attorney-General, to collect intelligence by means of listening devices, searching of premises and the interception of mail. To protect individual privacy as far as possible, consistent with the need for ASIO to perform its statutory functions, only officers nominated in writing by the Director-General of Security may exercise the authority of a warrant. At present, these written authorisations must be made for each warrant. The proposed amendment of section 24 of the ASIO Act will allow the Director-General to appoint particular senior officers of ASIO to perform the function of authorising those who may exercise the authority of a part III warrant. The amendment will enhance administrative efficiency without in any way diminishing ASIO's existing accountability in the exercise of its powers under warrant.

As to the final amendment of the ASIO Act, ASIO officers are not employed under the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922 but under terms and conditions determined by the Director-General of Security. This means that they cannot apply for vacant jobs in the Australian Public Service unless those jobs are advertised as being open to the general public. In view of the restructuring which ASIO has been undergoing, it is appropriate to enable officers of ASIO to apply for positions in the Australian Public Service. The object of this proposed amendment to the ASIO Act is to put officers of ASIO in the same position as officers of the Public Service when applying for vacancies. Officers will compete on their merits and, if found suitable, may be appointed as if they were already a public servant. All appointments will be treated as promotions to allow for appeals by other candidates if applicable.

There are several amendments being made to the Crimes Act 1914. Clauses 10 and 11 of the bill implement recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission from its report entitled Multiculturalism and the Law in relation to the sentencing of federal offenders. The amendments will ensure that an offender's cultural background must be taken into account by a court when it is relevant to the sentence or order that the court will make, including when deciding whether to dismiss the charge, or discharge the offender on conditions without recording a conviction.

The amendments in clauses 12 and 13 of the bill also relate to court orders made under the Crimes Act. They will ensure that where courts impose conditions which include monetary amounts in recognisances—or bonds—made under paragraph 20(1)(b), the offender cannot be imprisoned for breach of a such a condition, and that where a federal offender commits an offence whilst on a recognisance, breach action may be taken, even if the order has expired at the time the person is convicted of the new offence.

Clause 13 will also extend the range of options available to a court, where a person has breached a recognisance which has either a suspended sentence of imprisonment or a partially suspended sentence of imprisonment attached to it. The proposed amendments will enable the court to impose a monetary penalty not exceeding $1000, extend the period of good behaviour, or revoke the order and impose an alternative to imprisonment, such as a community service order.

The bill also makes amendments to the `escape' provisions of the Crimes Act which create offences relating to the escape of federal offenders. The most significant aspect of these amendments is the removal of Australian Capital Territory prisoners from the ambit of the provisions. The Commonwealth is no longer responsible for ACT criminal law and the ACT has now enacted its own escape provisions.

Finally, the amendment to section 85ZKB of the Crimes Act will remove scanning devices from the scope of the offence created by that section. Section 85ZKB prohibits the manufacture, advertising, display, offering for sale, sale or possession of equipment which is capable of being used to intercept a communication contrary to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. Scanners are radio receivers which can automatically scan all broadcast radio communications and tune into whatever may interest the operator. They are capable of receiving telecommunications which are in part transmitted by radio signals: for example, cellular mobile telephones as certain prominent members of society have found to their chagrin.

That scanners currently fall within the scope of section 85ZKB of the Crimes Act is an unintended result of the development of telecommunications technology which in part makes use of radio signals. I am advised that there are some three million scanners in use in Australia although it is, of course, impossible to confirm that number. The government does not believe that it is reasonable to prohibit the manufacture, sale or possession of a device which is readily available and has a number of legitimate uses apart from the possible interception of telecommunications. However, it hardly needs to be stressed that unauthorised use of a scanner to intercept telecommunications partially transmitted by radio signals remains an offence under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 as does subsequent unauthorised publication of any material collected in this way.

Amendments to the Transfer of Prisoners Act 1983 are being made so the ACT can be admitted into the national uniform interstate transfer of prisoners scheme as a participating state. At present ACT prisoners are covered by the Transfer of Prisoners Act 1983. Following ACT self-government, the Standing Committee of Attorney-Generals, SCAG, considered the issue of the interstate transfer of ACT prisoners for welfare and trial purposes. The Cairns meeting of SCAG, held on 11 and 12 July 1991, decided that the ACT would be admitted to the national uniform interstate transfer of prisoners scheme, and it was agreed that the legislation of each jurisdiction would be amended to recognise the ACT as a participating state for the purposes of the scheme. The amendments implement that decision.
Finally, the schedule to the bill makes amendments to a number of acts. Again, I only propose to deal with the more significant of these amendments.

Amendments will be made to the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991, the Crimes (Hostages) Act 1989, the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976, and the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990 to transfer responsibility for issuing certificates relating to the entering into force and operation of certain multilateral treaties from the Attorney-General to the ministers who are responsible for the treaties. The amendments will also remove requirements for gazettal of these certificates where this requirement exists. Gazettal was originally required to enable copies of the Gazette to be tendered in court proceedings. However, this is not necessary in practice, since a new certificate may be issued each time.

An amendment to the Customs Act 1901 will ensure that, where a claim for recovery of items forfeited under the act is made but not pursued, the goods are automatically condemned as forfeited to the Commonwealth when the claim is discontinued or dismissed for want of prosecution. Currently, separate proceedings must be instituted for condemnation resulting in extra costs to the claimant as well as to the Commonwealth.

Two amendments are made to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983. The first will give the director the function of appearing in proceedings or inquiries held under the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991. Australia is bound by international conventions to hold such inquiries or proceedings in relation to hijacking and similar offences on aircraft involved in international civil aviation. The amendment will ensure that experience in these matters is concentrated in one body. Inquiries and proceedings under the Crimes (Aviation) Act are also to be included among the matters in which the director can give undertakings of immunity to witnesses.

The second amendment concerns court orders prohibiting or restricting the publication of evidence or information in certain cases to prevent prejudice to the administration of justice. Courts already have this power in relation to civil remedy and recovery of pecuniary penalty actions instituted by the director. The amendment will expand these categories to include proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 seeking restraining orders over property, or the extension of the period of operation of such orders. Before such an order can be granted, the court must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the defendant committed a serious offence: a serious narcotics offence, an organised fraud offence or a money laundering offence. Satisfying the court of these matters often involves affidavit evidence which reveals details of witnesses or of an investigation. In some cases the court may need to make an order prohibiting or restricting the publication of this evidence to protect a witness or to ensure the effectiveness of a continuing investigation.

Amendments to the Extradition Act 1988 made by this bill will ensure that Australia can fulfil its international obligations under the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Maritime Navigation and the related Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Fixed Platforms Located on the Continental Shelf. Australia's accession to the convention and protocol took effect on 20 May 1993. The convention and protocol are designed to prevent and suppress maritime terrorism and they list offences in relation to acts likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship or the safety of a fixed platform. Those offences are extraditable within the terms of the convention and protocol.

As extradition will not be granted for political offences under the Extradition Act, it is necessary to put beyond doubt that the convention and protocol offences are outside the definition of `political offence' in that act. The amendment therefore excludes those offences from the definition of `political offence' for the purposes of the Extradition Act. The `political offence' definition has been limited in this way for a number of other multilateral conventions to which Australia is a party.

The bill makes an amendment to the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 to enable Australian Federal Police officers performing customs functions on Christmas Island to receive reports on the transfer of currency into or out of Australia under section 15 of the act.

Finally, amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 made by this bill will ensure that the act can be applied by regulation to one country for one or more of the following three purposes:

SPEECH.PARA: .to give effect to a bilateral treaty which provides for mutual assistance in relation to limited subject matter only;
.to give effect to a non-treaty bilateral arrangement providing for mutual assistance in relation to other subject matters; and

.to give effect to our mutual assistance in criminal matters obligations to a country which, with Australia, is party to a multilateral treaty or convention which contains mutual assistance obligations.

I conclude by again pointing out to the committee that this second reading speech demonstrates the urgent need for provisions which enable ministers or other persons to table second reading speeches without reading them. I commend the bill to the House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—I thank the parliamentary secretary for his comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks by saying that, were the suggestion of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) to be picked up by the government, his colleagues would be deprived of listening to the melodious tones of his voice on so many occasions.
—Your comments are noted too.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is another piece of legislation which indicates that the parliament works. Unfortunately, our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tends to refer to the Senate as unrepresentative swill. However, having looked at this bill, its genesis and the procedures that it has followed to achieve the form that we are now debating, one can only conclude that the Senate is a vital house of review. The Senate is, indeed, a very important part of this parliament in making sure that the legislation which ultimately becomes law is legislation which is suitable, legislation which is well considered and legislation which does not have bugs which have to be ironed out subsequently.

PARA.TAB: I also notice that the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is now what is termed an `omnibus bill'. This means that a large number of pieces of legislation are amended as a result of this one bill. Indeed, I understand that the government is seeking to make amendments, in some cases major and in other cases minor, to 17 acts of the Commonwealth parliament under this omnibus bill.

The opposition is not opposing this particular piece of legislation but, once again, I would like to register my concern at the way in which the parliament seems to be bringing in more and more omnibus bills that seek to amend a very large number of pieces of legislation which bear little or no relation to one another. These omnibus bills mean that, if I want to see what acts the Commonwealth has passed in amending legislation, or if I want to keep up to date with legislation, I will need to acquire a large number of different acts. I also suspect that consolidation of acts has not occurred as much as it should.

If a person was particularly interested in one area of the law he or she might have to buy the principal act, along with various amending acts. With these large numbers of omnibus bills passing through the parliament, it will be very difficult to track down just what the law is in any individual area. I think the government would do well to look at this procedure to see whether it could be improved to make sure that when omnibus legislation relates to acts which have some common thread.

It is not adequate for the parliamentary secretary or the minister to come in here and say, `We are going to bring forward this legislation to amend 17 acts. These acts have nothing in common with one another but these are the 17 acts this week that my department feels ought to be changed and amended.' We could more easily understand what the law is, and what the changes are, if we had amendments to particular pieces of legislation being dealt with with legislation similar to the legislation being changed, rather than an omnibus grab bag such as we have before the chamber this morning.

When the coalition got to see this omnibus bill, we decided, as we always do, to consult widely in the Australian community. We have been in touch with the various state and territory Attorneys-General, the state and territory police commissioners, and the shadow minister assisting the leader on multicultural affairs. Of course, we have also contacted the Australian Federal Police Association, the Public Service Union and ASIO.

This bill is to amend certain acts relating to criminal or law enforcement matters and for related purposes. I have just mentioned that the 17 acts that are being changed do not bear any particular relationship to one another but, for reasons of convenience, they are being amended under the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. Significant aspects of the bill include amendments to the ASIO Act 1979, and this is amended by section 24 being repealed and replaced to allow the Director-General of Security to give a standing authorisation to an officer of ASIO to approve persons who are able to exercise the authority of warrants issued by the Attorney-General. Consultation with the Director-General of ASIO has indicated that this amendment is considered to be quite acceptable and it is not controversial.

Section 16A(2)(m) of the Crimes Act 1914 is being amended to require a court to take cultural background into account when sentencing federal offenders and to include cultural background as a consideration when discharging offenders without proceeding to conviction—section 19B(1)(b)(i). The amendment adds cultural background to those of character, antecedents, age, means, and the physical or mental condition of the person.

These amendments were recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report entitled Multiculturalism and the Law. While it is the case that many factors relating to the circumstances of an offence are taken into account at sentencing, and there are circumstances where cultural background is relevant to the commission of an offence, we want the government to make it clear that this amendment is not intended to allow offenders to claim that their sentence should be reduced simply because of their cultural background. The Australian Law Reform Commission referred to this possibility but it was confident that the courts in their discretion would use the legislation appropriately. This is one of the matters that have been referred to the Senate committee as a result of the debate in the other place.
The Crimes Act 1914 is being amended further, at section 20(2A), to read:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is not to be imprisoned for a failure, under an order made under subsection (1), to pay an amount by way of reparation, restitution or compensation or an amount in respect of costs.
