The amendment appears to say that someone who has the benefit of not having a sentence passed, by virtue of an order being made to that effect, but who has breached the order, cannot be sent to gaol for the breach. Currently, however, such a breach can result in the person being dealt with in any way allowed by the act for commission of the original offence. This means, in effect, that the court can exercise its leniency in favour of a defendant who, if he rejects by breaching the relevant order the opportunity that the leniency offers, cannot be sent to gaol for breaching the order but can be dealt with almost as though the special non-custodial order had never been made.

PARA.TAB: The government tells us—I have no reason to disbelieve it on this occasion—that there is no increase in outlays by the Commonwealth as a result of this legislation. During a debate in the other place, Senator Vanstone, the shadow Attorney-General, put forward the coalition's point of view. As a result of the cooperative atmosphere in the Senate, this bill was sent off to the Senate standing committee and it was also looked at by the Senate scrutiny of bills committee. I am pleased that the government has accepted the amendments suggested by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In doing so, the government clearly took into account the evidence that was placed before that committee in relation to the question of cultural background.

I outlined a moment ago the concerns that we had in relation to the inclusion of cultural background but, when the act includes the approach that other matters should be taken into account by courts when sentencing people, probably cultural background should indeed be included. The other point of view would be that we appoint people to our courts who are of very balanced approach, who are able to make an assessment of sentencing options and who when sentencing are able to take into account all the circumstances surrounding a particular offence. I suppose the other way to approach it would be to remove all of these matters which courts are required to consider and leave it up to the judge's commonsense or the magistrate's commonsense, as the case may be.

The parliament has chosen to go the other way, by including matters that courts must take into account when sentencing offenders. If that is the way we wish to do it, as we have done it, the opposition certainly is not opposed to the inclusion of cultural background as a relevant matter to be taken into account by the court when sentencing federal offenders. It is highly likely that, even prior to this amendment, courts in Australia have taken into account cultural background. Those courts would include courts exercising federal jurisdiction.

I emphasise that it is important to realise that, by the form of legislation proposed in the bill, cultural background will be relevant not to guilt or innocence but simply in determining an appropriate sentence. That is something that really ought to be stressed. Certainly, it is appropriate that this is an aspect which is taken into account at the time a sentence is imposed. It would be unfair, however, to say that, because someone is of Aboriginal background and because Aboriginal tribal law permits a person to be killed in certain circumstances, in the Australia of 1994 such an Aboriginal would be entitled to kill in accordance with Aboriginal law even though, under Australian law and law the world wide, such an act could not be permitted. In this context one could consider other matters also.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has talked about the question of female genital mutilation. There is a great abhorrence in Australia of the practice of female genital mutilation and members on both sides of the chamber have expressed their concern in relation to this particular offence against women. If the law of Australia is changed, I certainly will be pleased that, just because a person comes from an ethnic background where this practice has indeed been the norm, that would not be a sufficient reason to allow that person off the hook. This really must be stressed because some people in the community would be suggesting that the inclusion of the words `cultural background' might mean that some people in Australia, because of their cultural background, are permitted to do things that other people are not.

It is important to realise that we are one people in Australia. We are one nation and the laws binding all of us should be the same. However, given the diversity of the ethnic make-up of some parts of Australia now, it is obviously appropriate that cultural background should be included as one of those matters which courts should take into account when sentencing a person after a person has been found to have breached the law. The committee also reached some conclusions in relation to breach of bond, namely that parliament should be vigilant in ensuring that the laws its passes will not enable offenders to receive some forbearance in sentencing to later abuse this indulgence.

It is interesting to note that the committee of the Senate was satisfied that the amendments proposed in the bill would not lead to any such abuse. The amendments were widely supported in evidence before the committee, were seen as being crucial by the ultimate Commonwealth protection authority and remedied some obvious but minor deficiencies in the existing legislation.

Another matter I would like to refer to is a result of examination of the bill by the Senate scrutiny of bills committee. A few minutes ago I highlighted what an important role the Senate plays by way of review. It is very important that the Senate tries to make sure that the legislation does not have bugs in it. This legislation was examined by the Senate scrutiny of bills committee and it resulted in amendments being suggested by the government, which we accept also. Those amendments relate to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act of 1979.

A change has been made to clause 6 dealing with the delegation of power to authorise warrants. The category of officer was changed from officer to senior officer. It is really important that, if powers are given to the Director-General of ASIO to delegate powers to someone, those powers should not be delegated to the most junior person working in the organisation.

The parliament obviously is very hesitant about allowing delegation of the very senior and serious responsibilities given to people such as the Director-General of ASIO, but we accept that, to enable the organisation to operate efficiently, at times it is necessary for the Director-General to say that it is not possible for him to do something but that someone else should attend to it. So it makes sense that there should be a provision in legislation permitting the Director-General to make these delegations, but it is vital that the delegations are made to people who are of a senior rank, people who are able to use those delegations responsibly. I am very pleased that the government has accepted that suggestion. The coalition very strongly supports that provision.

There was also a provision in the amendments in relation to the ASIO Act that, instead of having to make an authorisation on each occasion it is required, standing authorisations to senior officers of ASIO can be made. I think that is imminently sensible.

As I mentioned, the coalition has consulted widely throughout the Australian community on this particular piece of legislation. There were a couple of bugs which were, in fact, highlighted—the use of word `bugs' is a freudian slip and an unfortunate term to use when one is referring to ASIO. These hiccups were looked at and considered. They were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and to the Senate scrutiny of bills committee, with the result that some changes were suggested. The government has clearly accepted those changes and, as a result, the bill before this Committee has been improved.

The opposition supports this bill. The opposition was concerned and is pleased that the procedures I have outlined have been followed. I hope these procedures are followed in many more bills. Ministers often come to this Committee, the chamber or the Senate and have to rectify bad legislation which should not have been passed in the first place. The procedures that have been followed in this bill indicate that we are moving some way along the road to iron out those problems before they actually get on the statute books.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus bill with no central theme. It amends a number of acts administered within the justice portfolio. There are two aspects of the bill on which I would like to focus today: firstly, the amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 in relation to the cultural background of an offender; secondly, the amendments to four acts relating to the entering into force and operation of certain international conventions.

PARA.TAB: The Crimes Act 1914 lists matters which a court must take into account when passing a sentence or making an order in respect of a person convicted of a federal offence. The matters already listed include: the nature and circumstances of the offence; the personal circumstances of any victim of the offence; the character, antecedents, age, means and physical or mental condition of the person; and the probable effect that any sentence or order under consideration would have on any of the person's family or dependants.

The bill will add the words `cultural background' to this list. The effect of this will be to make the cultural background of a convicted federal offender a matter which a court must take into account when passing sentence or making an order. One could interpolate and say that, if the Crimes Act did not specify any matters, it would not be necessary to introduce the cultural background of the offender. But, given that there is something of a checklist for the judges and magistrates to refer to, an exclusion of an item such as the cultural background could suggest an intention that it not be taken into account. This amendment is appropriate.

There is a second place in which the cultural background of an offender will be relevant. Where a charge for a federal offence is proved, the court is empowered under the Crimes Act to dismiss the charge or to discharge the offender if the court is of the opinion, having regard to matters listed in the relevant part of the act, that it is not expedient to inflict any punishment or to inflict any punishment other than a nominal penalty or that it is expedient to release the offender on probation. The matters listed in the act in this regard include: the character, antecedents, age, health or mental condition of the person; the extent, if any, to which the offence is of a trivial nature; and the extent, if any, to which the offence was committed under extenuating circumstances. The bill will add to this list the concept of cultural background. Accordingly, the effect of this amendment will be to make a federal offender's cultural background a factor which a court may take into account in determining whether to proceed to a conviction.

As has already been pointed out by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), the bill is not proposing to make an accused's cultural background a defence to a federal criminal offence. The amendment is designed to implement recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission report entitled Multiculturalism and the Law. In that report, the ALRC unequivocally rejected introducing a defence of cultural background to absolve, partially or completely, an accused from criminal liability. Equality before the law is such a fundamental basis of our system of justice that it would be quite inappropriate for such a defence to be introduced.

It is, however, a relevant consideration to be weighed by the court at the stage in which an accused has already been found guilty. At the same time, offenders should be under no misapprehension that their sentence should be reduced simply because of their cultural background.

This bill was introduced in the Senate on 30 June 1994, and the provisions relating to cultural background are aspects of the bill that were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on 25 August. The committee presented its report in September. In its report, the committee noted that taking cultural background into account in sentencing was endorsed by, among others, the Law Council of Australia, the New South Wales Bar Association, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, the National Children's and Youth Law Centre, and Mr Martin Sides QC, of the New South Wales bar. The Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions did not oppose the recommendation that cultural background be taken into account in this way. The evidence before the committee was overwhelmingly in support of including cultural background as a relevant matter in the sentencing of federal offenders. This aspect of the bill is supported.

The second aspect of the bill is various sections of various acts which are being repealed and new sections substituted. The acts in question are the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991, the Crimes (Hostages) Act 1989, the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976 and the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and the Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990. The acts themselves are not terribly pertinent to my comments. The effect of the provisions to be repealed is that they allow the Attorney-General, by notice in the Gazette, to declare that a specified international convention entered into force for a specified country, including Australia, on a specified day, or that a specified country denounced a specified international convention and the denunciation took effect on a specified day. Secondly, they provide that a certificate signed by the Attorney-General certifying matters concerning notices given to the International Civil Aviation Organisation is prima facie evidence that matters certified in the notices was given to the organisation.

The principal effect of the provisions to be substituted will be simply to transfer the power to issue notices and certificates from the Attorney-General to the minister responsible for administering the relevant convention or conventions, and will remove the requirement for notices to be gazetted. The matter is not of great moment. The only comment that I will make on the substance of the proposed amendments is that one hopes that appropriate procedures would be enforced in the relevant departments to ensure that the appropriate requirements of international law are met. If this means seeking the advice of the Attorney-General's Department at an appropriate time in an appropriate way, that should be done.

I have some brief, general comments to make on the subject of treaties and conventions. This is a contentious subject and it is not only under debate within the government, as I will indicate, but also is the subject of considerable debate within the coalition parties. It reflects concern within both the business community and the community generally, and it particularly reflects the concern of those with an interest in the protection of the position of states under the constitution.

The power to make a treaty is an executive act which is derived from the prerogative of the Crown. Under our written constitution, the constitutional power to make treaties is derived from section 61, which provides for the executive power of the Commonwealth to be exercised by the Governor-General. Neither in relation to constitutional convention nor in our federal constitution is there provision for parliament to become involved in the treaty making process, except where legislation is necessary to implement a treaty. However, a number of procedures have been put in place over the years, at least since 1919, which have involved parliament. Currently there is effectively no procedure through which parliament has a role in relation to the making of a treaty. Some practices have been introduced and allowed to fall into disuse, and other practices have been proposed. The most recent comment from the government is a joint statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) which was issued on 21 October 1994.

The impact of treaties is widely recognised, and the necessity for some treaties to be negotiated within the confines of government and not revealed publicly except at appropriate times is recognised as a necessity also. That sort of treaty would be a bilateral defence treaty or something of a similarly sensitive nature. Other treaties have involved the community in a big way. It is a coincidence that yesterday, 16 November, was the day upon which the Convention on the Law of the Sea, a most important treaty, actually came into operation by reason of being ratified by 60 subscribing states, of which Australia is one. The manner in which the government treats the treaty making process obviously varies with the nature of the process under which it is negotiated and the subject matter, but the simple fact is that the government treats the parliament with scant regard.

In the joint statement the two ministers assert that the provision of information through the tabling of treaties and the publication of information relating to multilateral treaties under negotiation in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade publication Insight will be supplemented. It is said that wherever possible the government will supplement the information flow by now tabling all treaties other than sensitive bilateral ones before action is taken to adhere to them. `Before action is taken to adhere to them' is a little ambiguous, to say the least.

A treaty goes normally through at least two stages from the point of view of a signatory state. One is the process of negotiation and agreement, which is concluded by the signing on behalf of the state, and the second significant point is that it is then ratified by the signing state in a subsequent step. As in the case of the law of the sea convention, it does not automatically mean the treaty itself will come into operation, because there may be provisions in it that prevent it from coming into operation until the occurrence of some minimum condition such as a minimum number of signatories ratifying it.

A treaty imposes an obligation on a ratifying state, at international law, to implement the obligations undertaken, as required, within municipal law; that is, within the domestic laws of the state. From the sentence that I referred to from the joint statement of the ministers, it is not clear that it is compatible with the government's supplementing the information flow by tabling treaties, other than sensitive ones, before signature, before ratification or before implementation of the treaty in domestic law.

The two ministers, I am advised by representatives of the media, conducted a media conference following the release of the statement. The explanation offered at this point seems to be that the information flow will be supplemented by tabling all treaties before action is taken to implement them in international law. If that is a supplementation of information flow which is meant to be of benefit to the community, it is absurd. It does nothing. I think the silence of the media in relation to this particular statement reflected the attitude the media took to what was being offered.

The joint statement suggests that steps will also be taken to increase the possibility of participation by members of parliament in various treaty negotiating delegations. That has occurred in the past; it is something that is to be commended. But the manner in which members of parliament are to be selected and briefed, and the role which they are to play, is not dealt with at all. Obviously, it would be a difficult matter, which would require different considerations in different situations. But it is a hollow offer, containing no detail at all.

Finally, the minister has offered to provide full briefings on treaties under consideration or negotiation to any member or senator who asks for them. I hope that opportunity is taken up. But, having regard to briefings I have received from the government when I have requested them, I do not have any confidence that the briefing will be significant or detailed.

What is totally missing is any genuine proposal for consultation with the community. In January this year, the Business Council and seven other organisations issued a joint press release criticising the government for entering into treaties affecting business, and imposing cost on business, without consulting business as to the effect of those treaties. The Business Council and, on this occasion, 11 organisations issued a further press release in April this year, complaining of the same thing in more detail and in more vehement terms.

State governments are very critical of the manner in which the Commonwealth government enters into treaties, sometimes apparently with the purpose of ensuring that the Commonwealth's legislative power under the constitution is extended by the use of the existence of the treaty to enable legislation to be passed based solely on the external affairs power. We have had two bills debated in the House of Representatives in the last month which were based on the external affairs power. The significance of that to the states is not to be underestimated, because, ultimately, it means that if treaties are entered into legislative power can be extended across virtually any subject matter whatever. The role of the states, recognised and defined under the constitution, could be eliminated. It is inappropriate and wrong, and should not happen.

The state governments also have a complaint, which seems to be fully justified, that the process established for the consultation by states in relation to the negotiation and entering into of treaties does not provide an effective means of consultation with state governments. In fact, the matter was of concern as long ago as 1987, when the Constitutional Commission was conducting its investigations and the possibility of the establishment of a treaties council was ventilated in its final report.

This is an important subject. The government is treating it with scant respect and I think the community, reflecting the views of states and industry, will ensure that something has to happen to improve the current treaty making process.
I do not propose, Mr Deputy Speaker, to deal with the other aspects of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Main Committee for long because many of the points on this matter have already been raised by my learned colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) and we are very appreciative of the often important legal advice he is able to give us in the coalition ranks.

PARA.TAB: As we know, the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is to amend certain acts relating to criminal law enforcement matters and for related purposes. The bill amends 17 acts. As I think has been mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the bill was examined by the Senate scrutiny of bills committee and it was also referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was referred for examination those provisions of clause 9 which related to cultural background and to a breach of order, something that I think many in the community would have some interest in in relation to differentiation because of a person's cultural background. The evidence before the committee was overwhelmingly in support of including cultural background as a relevant matter in the sentencing of federal offenders, and it is a matter that many courts consider now already.

In the form proposed in the bill, cultural background will be relevant not to guilt or innocence but simply in determining an appropriate sentence. The committee's conclusion as to breach of bond was that parliament should be vigilant in ensuring that the laws that it passes will not enable offenders who receive some forbearance in sentencing to later abuse this indulgence. The committee was satisfied that the amendments proposed in the bill would not lead to such abuse. The amendments were widely supported, were seen as crucial by the ultimate Commonwealth prosecution authority, and remedy some obvious but minor deficiencies in the existing legislation.

The examination by the Senate scrutiny of bills committee resulted in government amendments to the bill regarding the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979. Change was made to clause 6 dealing with the delegation of power to authorise warrants and the category of officer was changed from officer to senior officer. As was noted by the opposition in the Senate, in particular by Senator Ellison from Western Australia, the government must be terribly careful that, where it is dealing with the delegation of power to authorise such warrants, the delegation is to a person of sufficient seniority, and not just anyone. Therefore the coalition supports the amendments.

I would have to say that Senator Ellison's points are rightly made because these days the drafting and issue of warrants is a serious matter, far more than was the case some years ago. We have seen that in recent times in the case of the inquiry into the bombing in Adelaide in relation to the NCA where a warrant was challenged and there was a problem with the warrant.

It is very important that that delegation of power to authorise such warrants be to a person of sufficient seniority. As Senator Ellison somewhat facetiously put it, you would not delegate to the office boy the ability to authorise a warrant. Therefore, as we said, the coalition supports the amendments and noted that in the Senate debate.

This bill involves some amendments that have workaday effects. The cultural background provision is quite an important one because it reinforces something that has already been undertaken in sentencing arrangements by courts. I would like to commend, in particular, the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone, and the other senators for their work in relation to the reference of the bill in the first instance to the scrutiny of bills committee.

The bill is an omnibus bill. The title of `law and justice legislation amendment bill' is often attached to these sorts of omnibus bills. This bill amends 17 acts, mostly in minor technical consequential ways. The points that were raised in the Senate bear repeating. One of the great dilemmas facing us in this modern era of legislation on just about every activity under the sun is that there are often technical or drafting errors or unclear elements in legislation that have to be tidied up; otherwise the legislation is unworkable or its intention is so unclear that it makes it very difficult for an interpretation to be made, particularly in the case of someone who is interpreting it for the benefit of a court.

In debates in the chamber yesterday in relation to the Racial Hatred Bill, we heard some very important comments from the honourable member for Tangney and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in relation to the question of explanatory memoranda, in particular, that there is an over-reliance by the government on explanatory memoranda to get it off the hook in relation to badly drafted legislation.

I referred yesterday to a particular instance and I will mention it again today. In the case of the training guarantee levy, the enabling legislation provided that, in the calculation of wages and costs, holiday and long service leave was not included as part of the overall calculation, but the explanatory memoranda included it. The difficulty was that, when anyone used or was governed by that legislation, it was extraordinarily difficult to arrive at the right answer when there were two conflicting points of view in the legislation and the explanatory memoranda.

Clearly, the explanatory memorandum has no authority in that case but, if someone were trying to interpret the legislation using the explanatory memorandum as a basis, it would be extraordinarily difficult, particularly if it was legislation which was not terribly clear in the first place. That has occurred on a number of occasions and it is one of the reasons we are here today debating what is basically an omnibus bill to clear up some legislation and to introduce reforms in other legislation.

The shadow Attorney-General in the Senate talked about being bright enough one day to use some sort of technological advance which will allow amendments to separate bills to be put in electronic form and to be distributed easily so people do not have to buy the old fashioned paper with 17 amendments and 17 bills. The sooner that day comes, the happier I will be. I can recall that, as a police officer, I used to spend the best part of my waking hours, when I was not out in the street, cutting out the amendments and pasting them in the acts. In those days, some of my colleagues were a bit slack at this; it was inspected and signed by the sergeant. I can well understand the shadow Attorney-General's worry about the increasing complexity of modern day legislation. As a consequence of the scrutiny of bills committee, an amendment allows the Director-General of Security to give approved officers of ASIO a standing authorisation to issue warrants on behalf of the Attorney-General.

The shadow Attorney-General pointed out that they had consultations with the Director-General. In the end, it was quite a sensible amendment to the bill, as it would clearly be acknowledged that there would be occasions when the Director-General would not be available to approve persons who are to exercise authority of warrants. If he is not available, it causes difficulty, and there is obviously no valid reason not to fix that. We would not want the thing to grind to a halt, purely and simply because the one delegated officer with the authority was unable to be present to exercise that authority.

But the difficulty was that, all of sudden, we had the situation where the authority could be given to any ASIO officer. For years, there had been the view that the authority could be exercised only by the Director-General and the intention was that he would give it to a person at a level. But, as a result of a drafting oversight in the initial legislation, that authority could have been given to any officer of ASIO. I agree with the shadow Attorney-General in her conclusion that the government did not intend this consequence. It was as a result of the spotting of that particular problem by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that the matter was addressed and tidied up.

It reinforces the importance of that scrutiny of legislation that is undertaken by the Senate and reinforces the very important role that the Senate plays within our constitutional system of representative government. Often, in the House of Representatives, the people's chamber, as we like to refer to it, there are occasions when the government pushes bills through in such an extraordinary rush that technical problems contained therein are only discovered when some poor unfortunate citizen is hit by some consequence of that particular legislation. The Senate is doing a great service for the rest of the community, because it is clear that, on many occasions, the government is quite unable to draft legislation that is clear enough, or sufficiently targeted in the first instance, to avoid some expensive legal process later on, in which people try to interpret the debates or whatever might have been contained in the explanatory memorandum.

I am conscious that the bill has been given a fair amount of debate in the Main Committee already. But there is one point I would like to raise in the concluding moments. It is a point that has fascinated me and, in a way, it fits in with some of the aspects of the bill. Some time ago—I do not have the questions to hand—one of our independent colleagues in the House of Representatives, the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), raised some questions about the taxation liabilities of a certain fellow called Guiseppe Verducci who, as some of us here would know, was involved in the Winchester inquest and was the owner of a property associated with the Bungendore Six affair.

Mr Mack asked whether or not a $300,000 taxation liability had been waived in the case of Mr Verducci. The House, by way of questions on notice, was informed that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) was unable to answer that particular question. Unfortunately, the minister is not here at the moment, but I would like to ask him, through this chamber, whether or not that is the case. It is my understanding that it could well be the case—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are going to raise that kind of thing, would you mind me asking him how much tax you paid last year?

—I would also ask—because this is one of the outstanding criminal justice issues of the 1980s—why that person's liability was waived. Was it as a consequence of some of his contacts with the ALP, as is being suggested in some of the popular newspapers?
—You know that that is spurious.
—I am of course very reluctant to make such a allegation but I must say—

PARA.TAB: Mr Elliott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable members opposite would know that in this particular instance it is not something that is a revelation. It has been canvassed, not in this particular aspect—
—Is it not true that the Leader of the Opposition does not pay tax at all?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The interjection by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) is totally out of order in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —This particular person's relationship with members of the Belconnen branch of the ALP has been the subject of some press speculation. All I ask is that in this instance, in the case of these particular circumstances, we can get an answer. I can understand that in some circumstances the question ought not to be answered, but this is a matter of some public importance. I would like to see whether or not it is the case that the $300,000 has been waived. An inquiry about this was made some time ago by the honourable member for North Sydney, by way of a question on notice. I might add that, during his evidence to the Winchester inquest, Mr Verducci made a quite colourful statement saying that he had supplied a kilo of cannabis to a former senior ALP figure.

PARA.TAB: The opposition supports the bill as amended. To reinforce my earlier comments, it is a tremendously important role that the Senate plays in our constitutional system of representative democracy, the Westminster system, by providing the scrutiny of bills that the government itself seems unable to provide. Many government figures—I am not sure of the views of all the honourable members present—share the opinion of the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), who is a very staunch advocate of abolishing the Senate. On the strength of this situation alone it can be seen that that would be a very detrimental step, not withstanding all the other issues that surround the existence and the role of the Senate in our system. One of the fundamental duties it performs most importantly is the thoroughgoing scrutiny of the legislation which is emitted from the government in the House of Representatives. I commend the senators for their work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, my understanding of the standing orders is that this Committee was not to be used for the kind of exercise we have just heard from the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). I suggest through you to the Presiding Officers that, if the chamber is to be used for that kind of exercise, there should be the opportunity for wider debate and for contending points of view. I thought from reading the standing orders that this Committee was to be used for issues on which there was agreement. To raise base allegations such as the honourable member has just raised does not do him any good at all. I thought the comments he was making were quite unworthy of him.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Moore knows very well that, when his party was in government, the information he was seeking—leading to the public revelation of a taxpayer's tax position—was never made available and cannot be made available by tax law. As a former serving officer in the police force, as a member of this parliament and as a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, he knows, better than anybody else in this room, that what he has been asking for cannot be provided. Despite that knowledge and that expertise, he proceeds to try to use that request for information virtually to defame somebody he does not want to name.

I suggest to the honourable member that it degrades his performance in this place and that, if he has accusations of that kind to make, he would afford the institution of parliament a great deal of benefit if he were to raise them in the other chamber, where they can be contested. I will suggest to Mr Speaker that, if this Committee is to be used for a bucket job—to be colloquial—we need to be looking at the standing orders in relation to the conduct of this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support what the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has said on this Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, and pay tribute to the job that the member for Moore has done, ever since he has been a member of this parliament, in raising issues of moment. I vividly remember, for example, the first occasion on which the member for Moore spoke in the adjournment debate in the House of Representatives. He initiated the debate on the subject of the Burke government in Western Australia and WA Inc. I was in the chair on that occasion, and I remember the speech very well. Ever since then, the member has properly raised issues of substance. We do not very often get people in this parliament with his expertise on the subject of law and crime.

PARA.TAB: However, having said that in relation to the bill, I feel constrained to respond to the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on the subject of whether what the member for Moore said could properly be said in this chamber. The member for Moore and I are both members of the Standing Committee on Procedure, which brought in the report that set up this chamber. We actually put in a dissenting report on this subject, and so we are both very familiar with what this chamber may or may not do. The member for Shortland is in error, and he needs to recheck the report and everything that has flowed from it in terms of debate in this chamber.

There was never a suggestion that there could not be disputation or contention in this chamber. There is, however, a requirement that no issues can be carried to vote here when there is disagreement between the government and the opposition. If there was any suggestion that, by virtue of a subject being referred here, opposition members could not properly raise contentious dimensions to those issues, then that would be a very big blot indeed on the copybook of the Keating government. I will not go into the subject of how this might be lamented.

However, it is quite proper, whilst not moving an amendment or moving against the second reading, for a member to raise topics which are germane to the legislation and which are controversial. If not here, where? These bills are referred here after the first reading. There is no second reading debate prior to their coming here. They come here by arrangement. There is no way of knowing whether any government or opposition member, in the course of his or her speech, is going to raise issues of contention on some legislation. There is, however, a general agreement between government and opposition at the time of referring that the bill itself is not going to be one that is likely to be subject to amendment. But even then the opposition does not commit itself to not move any amendments to any such bill—nor does the government agree not to move any amendments to a bill—by virtue of the bill being debated in the Main Committee.

In the case of there being amendments, the bill would have to go back to the House of Representatives for consideration. I think it has actually already arisen that bills which have been debated in the Main Committee have subsequently had amendments to them moved and debated in the House of Representatives chamber. Therefore the referral of a bill here is not meant in any way to constrain members on which matters they may raise that are germane to the bill. Since the member for Shortland chose to speak at some length on that subject whilst addressing his remarks to this bill, I felt that perhaps I could do so, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair has noted what has been said by both sides of the House, but I would remind members that the idea of this debate is to talk to the subject of the bill. If members wish to raise another subject, it should be raised on another occasion.
—In addressing this bill I might just address a couple of remarks to what the member for Moncrieff (Ms Sullivan) has said.

—No. I call you to order. I have already said that I believe the whole subject should be raised on another occasion, not as a part of debate on this bill. I have said that I believe that this matter is a matter bigger than this bill, and that it should be raised on another occasion; so I am just going to ask if there are any more speakers to the bill.
—On a point of order—
—I am sorry, I have made a ruling on this.
—Will you hear me on a point of order?
—Do you have another point of order, other than the one I have just ruled on?

—The point of order I was going to raise with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, was that the remark I was going to make would be helpful both to the chamber and to the chair, and might overcome what might be some misapprehension on both sides about the work this chamber does.
—I give the honourable member permission to speak for a short time.

—It is probably not unusual that the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) might be the one who wants to expand the work of this Committee. And given the way that the honourable member for Moncrieff has spoken, I think she is quite right in saying that we are seeing this chamber evolving to find its place in the spectrum of the work of the House.

PARA.TAB: Legislation will come here which will be amended or changed or debated. We said when we set up this chamber that it would consider non-controversial bills, and many of the pieces of legislation that the chamber looks at are non-controversial at first glance. However, we do not see a situation arising where, when things become controversial during debate on a bill, we are going to return the bill to the House. I think we have the maturity to be able to handle all the business that we get here.

The reason why we have put the benches less than two sword strokes away from each other is so that people might be a little less heated in their contributions, and it is easier to be less heated when you are closer. I always like to get close to the honourable member for Moore whenever I can because that becomes embarrassing for both of us! The point that the honourable member for Moncrieff made about how we should be able to handle almost everything here is quite valid.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask the honourable member for Watson to draw his remarks to a conclusion.

—The chamber might realise that and it will be a very useful method of evolvement of the work this chamber does. I would say to those in the chamber and to those who might read the Hansard that there is a role for controversy and heated debate in this chamber, as there is in the House of Representatives. While people can always trust the good faith of the Chief Opposition Whip and myself to try to find non-controversial bills, I am sure that we can also rely on our colleagues on both sides to find controversy in anything we might send here. I think that is the spirit in which we ought to adopt these things.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Sullivan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting really worried about the honourable member for Moncrieff because we are agreeing too much lately.
—I cannot call the honourable member again. Does the Parliamentary Secretary wish to speak to the bill?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not going to traverse the territory again, you will be pleased to know. I thank the members who have made contributions to this legislation. The bill has been thoroughly debated at this stage and I commend it to the committee.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT (FINANCIAL SUPPORT FUND) REPEAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to effect the repeal of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Act 1976, that authorised the ratification by Australia of the agreement to establish a financial support fund among OECD members. The fund was designed to assist OECD members facing serious external account difficulties following the oil price crisis of 1973-74 and was intended to supplement, on a last resource basis, other sources of credit to which members encountering serious difficulties have had recourse.

PARA.TAB: When proposed to parliament, the government saw the main value of the fund in terms of its capacity to help maintain healthy trading and financial relationships between the major countries, encouraging and assisting members to avoid unilateral trading restrictions. The bill was debated by parliament on 6 May 1976 and the corresponding act received royal assent on 25 August 1976. However, the corresponding legislation was not proclaimed.

The fund was never brought into effect, because of the failure of some other OECD countries (most notably the United States and France) to ratify the agreement. In the meantime, the world economy has already been exposed—and adjusted—to two major oil price shocks, the first one, which gave origin to this legislation, when the average crude price for petroleum more than trebled, from $US3.14 per barrel in 1973 to $US11.22 per barrel in 1974, and the second one, in the late seventies, when it rose from $US12.95 per barrel in 1978 to $US35.48 per barrel in 1980. With petroleum prices now fluctuating in the range of $US16-17 per barrel, equivalent to around $US5 per barrel in 1973 prices, we are now a long way back from the sense of emergency of the early 1970s.
As the need for the fund has now ceased the legislation should be repealed. I commend this bill to the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Repeal Bill 1994. This bill is to repeal the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (Financial Support Fund) Act 1976. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has indicated to the chamber, this arose from variations in oil prices back in the early 1970s. In fact, the act which is the subject of this bill, and therefore the act which will be repealed, arose from an agreement signed by OECD member countries, including Australia, in Paris on 9 April 1975.

PARA.TAB: The origin of this is in the period which immediately followed the intervention by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries into the world oil markets in 1973. Of course, this had serious consequences then for the non-OPEC countries: it transferred real income from these countries to oil producers. In the process, inflation was aggravated, the recession deepened and the balance of payments position of non-OPEC countries deteriorated. There was quite clearly a need at that particular time to look at legislation of this kind.

It is interesting to note that the parliamentary secretary made the comment in his second reading speech that part of the reason why this fund never came into existence was the failure of some other OECD countries—mostly notably the United States and France—to ratify the agreement. Amongst other countries, it was the administration of the United States which suggested—it was also suggested, independently, by the Secretary-General of the OECD—that the establishment of a financial safety net be brought into effect in the early 1970s. Despite that initial suggestion being made, the United States was one of those countries that did not ratify the agreement, and the need for that has passed.

In a second reading speech delivered on 6 May 1976, the then Australian Treasurer, Mr Lynch, said that the government saw the main value of the fund in terms of its capacity to help maintain healthy trading and financial relationships between the major countries. We welcome the changed situation which means that this fund does not need to be brought into existence, and healthy trading relations between the nations can continue without having to have recourse to such a fund. As I indicated at the outset of my remarks, the opposition supports the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Beddall)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Consideration resumed from 14 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to provide for a remission power in the Quarantine Act 1908 for fees charged for the provision of quarantine services by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). The remission power will allow revenue collections which are surplus to cost recovery requirements in a financial year to be returned to the relevant industry groups in the form of uniform fee rebates in the following financial year.

PARA.TAB: As a public monopoly providing regulatory services, AQIS needs to be able to justify its pricing policies to its clients. It also needs to make its costs and recoveries visible to them. An enhanced client focus is and will continue to be an integral part of the reform of AQIS announced in the 1994 budget.

Significant increases in industry activity and reductions in operating costs arising from the ongoing reform process resulted in surplus revenue from quarantine inspection activities of approximately $6.1 million during 1993-94.

Consistent with the closer relationship which AQIS has endeavoured to develop with its clients, the issue of an appropriate mechanism in which surplus revenue can be returned to the relevant industries has been the subject of detailed discussions with representatives of those industries. The fee rebate proposal has been developed as a result of these discussions.
I commend the bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine Amendment Bill 1994 provides the power to AQIS to refund money so that it can rebate a total of some $13 million to several industries that it has overcharged in recent times. There are many other industries that would also claim that they have been overcharged, but they are not getting a refund.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, at the insistence of various industries, recently established the Industry Charging Review Committee. This committee has determined that AQIS has overcharged various industries by a total of some $13 million and has now determined that this money must be rebated or refunded in various ways. The affected industry groups and the potential amounts involved are: the processed foods export sector, $1.319 million; plant exports, $4.732 million; live animal exports, $0.940 million; post-entry plant quarantine, $0.476 million; seaport quarantine, $0.774 million; airport quarantine, $1.132 million; and import clearance, $3.724 million. It is proposed that of the total sum of some $13 million, $1.6 million will be rebated through this legislation and $6.9 million through regulations.

The industries involved have been consulted about how they would like their money rebated or returned. Some have agreed to some of the money being used for specific projects such as quality assurance facilitation and residue testing programs, but the bulk will be used to provide fee rebates or fee relief during the current financial year.

While strict accounting has highlighted the fact that various industries have been overcharged, and they will now receive refunds, the largest area of inspection costs is in the meat industry overall but, in particular, the red meat industry. In this area, there will be no refunds. The costs remain far too high, but there will be no refunds because of the consistent problems of securing effective reform in this area.

Last year, the government set aside some $15 million for AQIS redundancies as part of its restructuring packages, but the money was not used. Why was the money not used? It was not used because of union resistance to reform and to the redundancies, a resistance which, as I will point out to honourable members in a moment, is putting at risk not only the efficacy and performance of our export meat industry, but also the jobs of those involved in it. It is a classic example of mates being anything but mates to one another in the meat industry.

The meat industry is hopeful that the coming Senate inquiry, for which we secured bipartisan support, will help ensure that costs are reduced. The minister indicated earlier this year not only that he would agree to the inquiry but also that he accepted the terms of reference which I felt were broadly necessary. That inquiry will, hopefully, highlight the question of how far the reform process has gone, but I suspect, worryingly, that it still has a long way to go.

This is a very important issue. Australia is a trading nation critically dependent upon trading performance for its prosperity and jobs for its people. For years the government has been intent on letting the world know that it needed to get its economic and trading house in order. It has been active in GATT, and we have supported that process. It is now active in terms of the APEC negotiations, and we support that. But the problem is that in certain areas at home we have had a very stubborn resistance indeed to the need to tackle some hard issues and some hard reforms. Now that we find ourselves looking at a more open market and looking at a situation where we are going to have to be more competitive than ever, not only because of GATT but also because of APEC, we have some big problems, because in many areas we are behind the eight ball—and we are dragging the chain very badly.

We have a problem in the area of our ability to obtain an adequate slice of ASEAN markets, but it is worse than that. There is clear evidence emerging that some areas of traditional Australian strength, in terms of our productivity and our capacity to do a good job at the right price, are seriously compromised here at home. This has been highlighted in quite a fascinating way by the recent proposal by the restaurant chain Sizzlers to import up to 190 tonnes of United States beef. It backed off that because there was a community outcry. Some of the community outcry, I have to say, was a bit misguided. It was along the lines of `You must keep this out because it is American beef, because it is American beef, because it is American beef. We ought to be able to use our own, and if we cannot compete then that does not matter.' It is competition that is the real problem here. We have to remember that we send some 300,000 tonnes of beef to America, so we can hardly complain if somebody wants to bring 190 tonnes of beef into Australia.

But what is worrying about this and what should send a chill down the spine of every Australian is that, if we look at it closely and we get behind the rhetoric about it being because of the drought—Sizzlers suddenly discovers now that it can source beef in Victoria, where the drought is not so bad anyway—we discover some very disturbing things. We start to get close to the truth about why Australia's economy will not fully recover unless real reforms are made, why we are staring down the gun barrel of a blow-out in our deficit, and why we will not be able to successfully trade unless we stop putting off the hard issues. I want to put it to the Committee simply that we are in danger of not only not being cost competitive on ASEAN markets, which we are consistently told we must now ensure that we perform on, but we are not being properly competitive domestically.

I want the committee to consider these very worrying facts. American cattle prices are currently, in our dollar terms, 60 per cent higher than those received by Australian farmers. The price is around $3.70 a kilo dressed weight in the US compared to $2.30 here, so the raw product would cost a potential importer like Sizzlers considerably more. Sizzlers would have to pay American farmers a lot more than it would have to pay Australian farmers for the raw material. So what happens then, presuming these people want to import this stuff? They put it through an American abattoir, or packer, as they put it, they slaughter the animal, they bone it, they pack it into boxes, they transport it in container form to the waterfront, they load it onto a ship, they sail it across the pond, they unload it on our notoriously expensive and inefficient wharves and they distribute it.

Astonishingly, after all of that, the rump steaks here, according to industry sources, remain at least price competitive and, according to a quite a substantial number of meat processors I have spoken to in the last few days, almost certainly cheaper than the Australian product. It is quite unbelievable. We have had report after report in this country saying reform is necessary. The government deserves, in my view, thumping condemnation for the appalling reality that, despite its endless rhetoric about our improving competitiveness, we are still just not making the grade.

One instance of this relates to the meat inspection costs. They are much higher in this country than they are in the US, as the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) knows only too well because he has got one of Australia's biggest abattoirs in his electorate. Not only are the costs much higher in this country but also the work practices—particularly the restrictive work practices engaged in by so many of the people involved—have for a long time effectively blocked improvements in reform and efficiency in other aspects of the meat processing industry, particularly on a case by case, site by site basis.

We have had report after report. The latest was from the Industry Commission. I do not know why the government keeps running Industry Commission reports because it never listens to the advice it is given. The latest report has just agreed with the seven, eight or nine that have gone before: the Australian beef industry is competitive on Asian and other export markets only because Australian producers are forced to accept significantly lower prices than they should have to accept, because our process and transport sectors and our government sectors—taxes and charges and whatever—are bogged down by outdated work practices and by excessive government involvement, red tape, costs and charges.

A very significant point that needs to be made is that we are in the midst of the worst drought we have seen for decades in this country. One of the reasons that the problem is so severe is that producers have been forced to accept much lower prices than they should have accepted for their produce. Depending on which report one listens to, the inefficiencies in processing, transport and inspection services are so severe that they have cost producers between $30 and $100 a head.

I do not know about other cattle producers in this room but it would have made a hell of a difference to me—and I confess to having a vested interest in this—and to the people that I represent if we had had that money in real terms for the last 10, 15 or 20 years. We might have been in a position to wear this drought far better. One of the things that needs to be clearly understood is that this is just yet another example of why the government is, in large part, culpable for the extraordinary circumstances pertaining to rural Australia today.

The government's contribution to drought is about $162 million over two years. It pales into insignificance when one considers what things like interest rates have cost the rural sector. Beef exports are now worth about $4 1/2 million a year. Imagine how much better off our major rural producers would be if they had had that extra $30 to $100—depending on who one listens to—in their pockets because the rest of the industry had been efficient.

The whole thing is now brought home to us in the bluntest imaginable fashion by the American industry. It is unbelievable that, in a country where we can produce the beef for less than the Americans, they can still land the stuff here for less than we can provide it in this country because the post-farm gate levels of performance in this country are so utterly abysmal that they push the price through the roof.

If we cannot compete effectively enough here on our domestic markets, what chance are we going to have of maximising our potential in Asia? Who will be the losers? Not only the farmers I have just mentioned but also the workers: the people who work in these plants, the people who are employed by the beef and the sheep meats industry. What is going to happen if we cannot maximise our performance in those sectors and we are not cost competitive when the drought breaks and when there is massive overcapacity—because that is what there will be? The dislocation will be enormous.

As for this nonsense that our unions go on with, we know they are protecting a few hundred jobs in AQIS, and that is standing in the way of major reform. They are putting at risk the prosperity and the jobs of many thousands of other Australians. It is about time a few people in this country started to wake up to the fact that if they behave in a troglodyte fashion they will often end up hurting the very people that they claim to be representing. It is time that these reports that I referred to earlier, which culminated in the IC report and which have been consistently ignored, are not ignored any more but are acted upon. It is time they were acted upon quickly and decisively, so that we can turn this thing around. There is no point in doing as some Australians have done in recent days and resorting to an old-fashioned, protectionist, `keep it out at all costs', tub-thumping sort of approach.

The question of Sizzlers' threatened importation of American beef must be seen for what it is: a clarion call to action. The beef industry itself, industry leaders and participants in it, are all for free trade. After all, Australia is somehow or other still the world's biggest beef exporter, but this case proves that we are severely limiting our own potential. We must get serious about giving our industry a competitive economic environment or we will continue to be steamrolled by countries that do.

Let me now turn to the specifics of AQIS's major customer, the beef industry, and the impact AQIS's performance has had on it. Beef is now Australia's largest rural industry, as I mentioned a moment ago. Over 70 per cent of product is exported. The industry—unsubsidised, efficient, export oriented and intent upon improving its performance—has managed to establish a very strong place in the liberalising Japanese market, and is opening up new outlets throughout Asia. It is a real performer; although, as I said earlier, it maintains that performance by forcing farmers to take a lower on-farm price than they should have to.

One of the major beef companies in this country at the moment is trying to have this industrial relations mess sorted out. I will tell you one of the major reasons why company representatives say it has got to be sorted out. They say that if we are not careful—if we keep screwing down growers' returns in this country—growers will not be able to provide the improvement in genetic performance that is vital to capturing and securing markets in the future in Asia. The Americans, the New Zealanders, the Argentineans and the Europeans will outstrip us in that vital area. There must be adequate returns to farmers. That is in the interests of the entire beef industry and, of course, of our export industries, if they are to remain fully world competitive. We have a situation where to date our farmers have been able to do it, but the other links in the chain need a bomb under them. Instead, of course, they have been blighted by inertia for years.

I can put some figures around the questions we were talking about a moment ago: how do the Americans get there, and why are they more competitive than we are? In major research about 18 months ago the MRC found that we were engaged in a fight to the death for market share in Asia, and now we find we are threatened even here at home. The Americans can process beef for as little as 16.5c a kilo. This is not some Third World country we are talking about, this is the wealthiest nation on earth, and their costs are 16.5c a kilo. The Argentineans and the New Zealanders are getting their costs down to the mid-20s—25 and 26c a kilo. In Australia, as of about 18 months ago, the cost in our best practice plants was in the high 40s—about 49c. That is double New Zealand and Argentinean levels, and three times American costs. Why? I think we have answered that question.

It is time we got on with effective reform. I cannot emphasise this too strongly. The major meat company I was talking about a moment ago, which is engaged in reform, is now trying to get through to its workers. Maybe it has been too slow, but at last it is trying to communicate with its employees. What is getting in the way? The unions in the middle. But the message that the company is trying to get over to the workers in its plants—and that I am now delighted to learn is starting to get through—is that the only way they are going to get a better return, the only way they are going to actually enjoy higher wages, is to improve productivity and do a better job. The company is making it plain that if they will do a better job it can reward these people more attractively. I think that is important.

Frankly, I have the greatest admiration for people who work in abattoirs in this country. I go through abattoirs very frequently. It is not pleasant work, and it is hard work. You see a lot of people who work very hard indeed in difficult and unpleasant circumstances. All power to them! I am all for better returns for them, but it is going to mean changing the way we do things. We still use the old, outdated tally system. Nobody else uses that, but the unions in this country stubbornly hang on to it. We have had inadequate capital investment for years. Why? Because we cannot get the flexibility we need to use the new capital equipment properly. That is why we are so far behind.

I say that in the interests of all involved it is time we stopped putting this off. For years we have had agreement that it needs to be changed from all players, except the unions in the middle—the AMIEU in particular and the Public Service Union representing AQIS. In case we need any further sobering up, I remind the chamber that in 1960 Australia was the fifth largest global exporter of processed foodstuffs—this is the area where our great future in Asia is supposed to lie—and today we are the 11th. We have not been improving; we have been slipping.

Australia has a chronic and now rapidly escalating problem with its trade imbalance as we supposedly pull out of the recession. We have to do better, not just for the sake of our farmers and our export earnings but in the interests of more employment, work opportunities and rising living standards for the people who work in these industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), one would think our meat industry was in a state of absolute collapse, that Australia was a totally inefficient producer, that it was unable to export and had a myriad of problems that we could not solve. However, we happen to be the world's biggest exporter, as the honourable member himself said. We happen to export hundreds of thousands of tonnes of beef to the United States. The member for Gwydir said something about 190 tonnes coming into Australia, and he made the conclusion, therefore, that we are in dire straits. Of course, that does not add up. We export hundreds of thousands of tonnes to Japan and to other markets in Asia. We are an extremely efficient and extremely large exporter of beef on the world scene—that cannot be denied.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say we cannot do it better or that there are not problems with AQIS. The costs are too high, and the government is committed to solving that problem. When the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he made a commitment to restructure AQIS, and that commitment is carried on by the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Collins). We will get there, but we will not get there by kicking unions or by kicking meat workers. The member for Gwydir himself said that they do a good job. They do hard work in bad circumstances, and their interests have to be considered in the whole equation.

We cannot say that everything that is wrong with an industry is due to the unions. Of course it is not, because there is a whole range of issues. We are efficient producers and we can be better. One of the areas in which we can improve our performance is the meat inspection area—there is no doubt about that—and the government is committed, and has been for some time, to restructuring AQIS. There are difficulties involved in doing that, but we are committed to getting a better result and to lowering the costs of meat inspection in abattoirs in Australia.

The principal amendment proposed by the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1994 is to provide the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy with the power to refund the whole or part of a fee payable by a person for a quarantine service provided by AQIS. In the past he has not been able to refund overcharged money, and that has been a flaw, I believe, in the legislation which is addressed by this legislation. The amendment will primarily affect our primary industries and, with much of rural Australia in the grip of a very severe drought, it is an important amendment that will provide some rural producers some relief from fees.
The second reading speech to the bill indicates that the reason for the proposed amendment is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to allow revenue collections which are surplus to cost recovery requirements in a financial year to be returned to the relevant industry groups in the form of uniform fee rebates in the following financial year.

The estimates by the government are that the surplus collections amounted to about $6 million in 1993-94. The National Party and the Senate estimate that the figure could be as much as $13 million, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy said the refund could amount to $15 million. But, whatever the figure, it is unlikely that there should be too much opposition from the industry in handing it back.

PARA.TAB: The minister's press release of 31 July foreshadowed that AQIS would soon be providing details of surplus revenue for 1993-94. Once those accounts were finalised AQIS would be discussing with the industry the manner in which the refunding of those surplus moneys would take place.

The minister has matched those words of 31 July with the legislation before us today. AQIS has said that its recovery areas in 1993-94 were in the areas of processed food exports, dairy, fish and dried food exports, livestock exports, grain exports and quarantine import clearance—that is, airports and seaports. It is difficult to understand why such legislation has not been with us in the past, and it is very difficult for AQIS or any other organisation to adequately estimate how much it would require from industry in order to conduct its activities. The logical thing is to overestimate what it requires so that it is not left short.

If we look at the collection system introduced for research and development in the beef industry, we get a fair indication of how difficult it is to calculate those collections. The cattle transaction levy, for instance, was introduced after some parts of the industry voiced strong opposition to the slaughter levy in existence at that time. AQIS set a fee of $6 payable each time a beast changed hands. The collections were way in excess of calculations, and the AMLC industry policy council has recommended to government, on several occasions since, that those fees be reduced. The government has acted each time on those recommendations and the fee is now down by about three-quarters to a quarter of what it was.

It is difficult to calculate the level of collections because it is almost impossible to predict the level of usage in certain operations. Predictions of costs and takings are difficult, and it is not unreasonable to expect that excess collections should be returned to the industry. In fact, it would be unreasonable to expect that they would not be. The explanatory memorandum in the bill explained that refunds would be structured for each industry group, in accordance with the agreements entered into with AQIS, through AQIS charging review committees. AQIS has established nine committees, one for each major sector of industry that AQIS services. They cover exports of meat, processed food, organic food and grain, horticultural exports and imports, live animal imports and exports, imported foods, quarantine import clearance and quarantine airports and seaports.

Members of this House would agree that AQIS performs reasonably well in respect of its food inspections and supervisory functions. The two areas that needed most attention were the development and supply of sound business practice in relation to planning and organising structure, and the encouragement and application of professional, technical and administration management and leadership skills at AQIS. Calls for changes in those areas have come from the concerns expressed by industry about the on-costs of AQIS services.

Once again, this government is responding to the concern of the rural industries. The member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), was trying to say that we were not responding, but of course we are responding. If we look at the meat processing industry we find one of the biggest reforms. The government is introducing competition on meat inspection services and, if AQIS wants to retain a share of the work in the future, it will need to be efficient. It is widely recognised that Australian farmers are some of the most efficient in the world. That is reflected by the extent of our meat exports, but those efficiencies are hindered by government charges and regulations. Changes that we have introduced to AQIS services, such as fees and refunded collections, now mean that we can retain the integrity of our food standards—which is extremely important—and we will also be able to deliver those services more efficiently to the industry and to the consumer.

Figures from the New South Wales Department of Agriculture show that the north coast region of New South Wales has an estimated 850,000 head of cattle. It is the region's single biggest income earner worth $140 million annually. It provides 13 per cent of the total production of beef in New South Wales. We have export abattoirs at Wingham, Macksville, Grafton and Casino—Grafton and Casino are in my electorate—and there are scores of smaller domestic works.

It is recognised along the east coast as an important nurturing ground where cattle are produced for fattening along other areas of coast. The beef industry on the north coast is spread over the entire region and is based largely on running breeding herds. Three-quarters of those herds produce weaners, with the remainder selling vealers and growing out and/or finishing steers. Store wether weaner producing herds are mostly run on native, lower quality pasture areas. Calves are in store condition at six to 12 months of age.

My electorate is also home to the largest meat processing plant in the Southern Hemisphere, the Northern Cooperative Meat Company at Casino. The Casino meatworks is capable of processing more than one million kilograms of dressed carcass each week and any reforms of AQIS operations are obviously of great importance. The meatworks have been very supportive of the government measures and its moves to introduce them.

If there were a loss of international confidence in the quality of our food, that would rip the heart out of many of our primary industries. When making efficiency savings to AQIS, governments have to be careful that it is only the cost and not the rigour of testing which is reduced. The slash and burn calls that we hear from the opposition—and heard a little while ago from the member for Gwydir—have the capacity to threaten our international reputation.

Over the past 18 months the government has progressively made efficiency gains through AQIS operations. It is the increased efficiency of the organisation that has led to this bill coming before the House. Costs have been reduced. We now have some unspent money to return to the industry. Further efficiency measures in AQIS remain a priority and a necessity for the government. When these measures are in place, we will be able to return more money to the industry. This bill allows us to do that, and it should receive the support of every member of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I get a bit tired of the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson) coming into this place and thumping the furniture in his attempt to make points. His apparent understanding of the beef industry compares to his lack of understanding of the wool industry.

PARA.TAB: This legislation follows a promise from the government to reduce costs. It returns AQIS money beyond its costs to the sectors of the industry from where the excesses came. That is certainly to be welcomed. When people talk about efficiencies they really have to analyse what they are saying. The member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) comes in here and, on this occasion, runs a very free trade line; on other occasions he is different.

What we really need in AQIS today is an ethos which does everything it can to expedite exports, but to take a much more conservative view on imports. There are obviously trade reasons for that, reasons which our competitors understand all too well, but there is another reason.
