Australia's relatively disease-free status does require us to err on the side of extreme caution in terms of entry of any product that could even remotely carry disease into this country.

There is no doubt in the big push for world trade, and in the widening of trade, that we are going to see an outbreak of the spread of diseases around the world, as occurred in history. The black plague spread through Europe on the heels of expanded trade and killed one-third of the people of Europe in the carnage it caused.

That sort of thing can happen and it will happen again. We have to be always vigilant about quarantine on imports to this country. I do not believe that we can err too far on the side of caution in this matter. If there is any risk at all, we should be saying no. I believe we should be saying no in this case and damn any GATT consequences. The member for Gwydir was running a very strange line. In his speech, he condemned the industry, and condemned the unions, and then spoke of his admiration for the workers, who are, of course, overwhelmingly members of the union. He also said that we are non-competitive and then mentioned how well we are doing with our exports. It was the usual plethora of statements that the member comes in and makes in a lot of his speeches. They are, of course, all made with the greatest authority and the greatest confidence. I think it typifies the oft held view that the emotional content is far greater than the facts in his contributions.

The company which was looking to import beef from America, Sizzlers, stated that it was looking to import beef not as a matter of price but as a matter of securing supply because of the drought in eastern Australia. The company also said that its customers had complained bitterly about this, so it looked around and found other sources of supply within Australia, which it did not know were available. It is quite clear that it was not something that was done on price. I know people in Western Australia who claim that, if they could access the export quotas, they could sell a lot more beef in Europe, but that they are being inhibited from doing so. That is a problem, but it is clearly not a problem that has anything to do with AQIS, rather it is a problem within the industry.

The lamenting at the low price Australian farmers receive for beef does have some merit. The price we receive is too low compared to the price in the importing countries. I believe the main reason for this is the vertical integration and foreign ownership of the industry. That is the main reason that prices are low. It is something that has been allowed to happen and it is something that we should take every opportunity to redress. We should find different marketing techniques into these countries. It is clear that we will be able to expand our markets into Japan. We are doing so in the face of the competition with the United States and we are doing it relatively successfully.

That is not to say that improvements cannot be made. As the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) said in his contribution, they can be made and we should be looking at everything possible to improve performance where we can. It is all very well for the member for Gwydir to come in here and lambast this government in respect of AQIS. But AQIS is not a new problem; AQIS is a longstanding problem. This government has done more to address the problem than was ever done by the previous government and of course that cannot, in all honesty, be denied. I think we are getting there but we can only get there if we have cooperation within the industry. It is simply counterproductive to take out the big sticks, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party wants to do, and bash and blame unions for the problems. If we want to get the answer, we have to address the real problems and not the ideological or imagined problems.

I am very concerned about the shape of the rural sector in Australia. I see new industries started and thwarted for a variety of reasons. The issue of an emu industry has been drawn to my attention recently. This is an industry which has enormous potential and it is an area in which Australia should have a monopoly because the emu, of course, is native to Australia. The industry was started in Western Australia, but we now have the situation where there are more emus in captivity in the eastern states than there are in Western Australia, and many more emus in captivity in the United States than there are in Australia. We are in danger of losing an industry which should be an indigenous industry. It is an industry in which we have a monopoly and an industry with a product of enormous world demand.

We see this in other areas. We see other people developing our flowers, probably better than we are, and I think we must ask ourselves why this is so. Of course, it is not all gloom. I believe the wool industry, through dint of its own resources and support from a sector of the government, is a good example, and I think the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) needs a lot of credit for the support he gave to the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority in the downstream processing of wool. It is going to be one of the great success stories, and in my view within the next decade it will again make wool Australia's biggest single export.

Returning to the Quarantine Amendment Bill, I think it is a very straightforward bill. It is, I am sure, a bill that must be endorsed by everyone. It is a bill that aims to reduce costs, and it addresses the accountability which the minister said he would put into AQIS. I believe that if the pressure is kept up in this area we will see those reforms. But at the end of the day this must be clear: the future for Australia is not as a low wage country. The future for Australia is only, and can only be, as a high wage country, and that means that with our high wages we are going to have to get productivity.

We do that in some areas: for instance, in the mining industry. Australian miners are without doubt the most productive in the world. Comparisons with South Africa show that we are much more productive than the South Africans are, particularly in the area of hard rock mining. This has been brought about with the development of a culture of excellence in the industry and a recognition from the workers of the very important part they play in the industry. I have a friend in Perth who is a mining engineer—a world-class mining engineer. In terms of deep shaft sinking he is probably the leading Australian expert. He tells me that having worked around the world he would rather work with Australians than anyone else. He says he can work with two fewer men on a platform in a shaft, and he says that Australian miners are much safer and smarter in their work than anyone else. He does not say they work harder—in fact, he gives that to the Irish—but he says that our miners are the best he has ever worked with. I believe that that ethos can be spread to other industries. There is no reason why we cannot develop that culture everywhere, because in my experience what workers overwhelmingly want is a fair go. They are not looking for rip-offs of profits. The ethos of a fair days's pay for a fair day's work is imbued in the Australian worker.

I believe there is not much more than can be said on this bill. It is certainly an initiative that fulfils the minister's promise. It is an initiative that I believe the industry should welcome, and I certainly hope it will lead to continuing improvements in efficiency and productivity, because there is no future for Australia as a low wage nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to outline the purpose of the Quarantine Amendment Bill, and I want to commend my colleague the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who spoke just before me. He was talking about Australia's future being as a high, wage nation and not a low wage one as is always advocated by the other side of the House. We need to make sure that in doing that we also protect our industries. AQIS, our Quarantine and Inspection Service, has done that extremely well in the past.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to allow the overpayments of fees that AQIS charged for quarantine services to be refunded in the form of fee rebates to the relevant industry groups. AQIS is a public body which has to be able to justify its pricing policies to its clients. It also must make its costs and recoveries visible to them. The word `transparent' is used a lot today. I think that is fair enough, for all government bodies should be transparent. They should show industries why they are charging certain fees. They should be able to justify their cost ratios.

Significant increases in industry activity and reductions in operating costs arise from reform processes, and there has been a lot of reform taking place through AQIS and in this area for some time. Those reforms are continuing and will do so for some time, I believe. They have resulted in a surplus of approximately $6.1 million during 1993-94.

This bill provides the mechanism for refunding that surplus to the industry groups. At the moment there are no remission powers in existence, hence the need for this bill. The industry groups that are affected and which would gain from the rebate are: the processed foods exports, $1.319 million; plant exports, $4.732 million; live animal exports, $0.940 million; post-entry plant quarantine, $0.476 million; seaport quarantine $0.774 million; airport quarantine, $1.132 million; and import clearance, $3.724 million. There will be some real benefits to these industries from this bill. The mechanisms and processes of the system have become much more efficient, and industry is now gaining from that.

Quarantine has been essential to Australia in the past. The object of AQIS is to prevent the entry into Australia of pests and diseases of humans, plants and animals, while facilitating the international movement of people and commodities. That is a big task and it takes a lot of coordination, a lot of specialist people and a lot of effort.

AQIS applies sound scientific principles to quarantine decision making. Through our geographic isolation and a strong quarantine policy, Australia has been kept free of many of the pests and diseases that have occurred in many other countries. Things are changing. The world is certainly much smaller in terms of travel and the breakdown of trade barriers, so there is more pressure now.

In economic terms, Australia's position has meant that our agricultural exports have had an advantage over those of many other countries. Tasmania is in a special position as it is an island attached to an island continent. It can be especially thankful for the far-sighted quarantine services that have been available throughout Australia over the years. Of course, the image of clean green that applies right around Australia is certainly being applied in Tasmania. We would be loath to have anything endanger the image that we are creating for ourselves on the island.

It is important that AQIS remains and becomes even more efficient than it is at the present moment. The job these days is being made more difficult by the increasing complexities of technologies and trade in micro-organisms and biological materials. Because of the opening up of new markets and the expansion of old ones, there are rapid increases in general trade. As countries become more affluent and distances are covered by air more quickly, more tourists can land on our shores.

We have had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Indonesia this week with the leaders of the Asian nations and the USA, looking at changing the trade regimes that have applied in all those countries over many years. That will open up great opportunities for us. Our Prime Minister has certainly done us proud in being able to be there. I read this morning that the President of the United States has said that he is the best frog puncher around, meaning that he keeps the issues live and keeps pushing on for the next round of talks and the next issues that have to be dealt with.

Our service has to keep up with all these changes and it has to do so by making sure that it is accountable to the industries that it serves. In 1988 there was a review of AQIS which has resulted in many changes and advances. The service has become very streamlined as a result of that review. AQIS is now delivering an improved level of service, with more transparent assessment of import applications and increased risk control over incoming passengers and cargo, as well as such things as ballast water and ship and aircraft waste. We have had some experience in Tasmania with ballast water coming from several tankers or woodchip ships on parts of the coast. This water has given us, we believe, a starfish which is now eating just about everything that exists on the bottom of some of our bays and harbours. We have quite a substantial shellfish industry in Tasmania and the starfish climb over each other until they eat everything that is on the bottom, then they start eating themselves. They continue till they find some further nutrients for them to expand on. It is complex and those are not simple issues to get on top of.

The job these days is being made more difficult by the increasing use of technologies. The fundamentals, however, remain the same—a service based on risk assessment and risk management principles. I have heard some argument about what the risks are, what risks we should base assessment on and what percentage of risks, et cetera. These fundamental principles are continuing to be assessed, reviewed and improved to ensure that Australia keeps its place in the forefront of the green clean trade which is now becoming our trademark. We must apply the same stringent rules even though there is a freeing up of the markets around the world. Free trade does not mean lowering standards and Australia has the most to lose if we become slack in our quarantine service.

I believe the meat industry is worth well over $3 billion in export dollars, probably $3 1/2 billion. The integrity of the service has to be maintained because of the dependence of the export meat industry on having a very good inspection service. The failure of that industry would be devastating to some regional areas of Australia and the livelihood of many country communities. In the community I live in, it would be devastating if for some reason the plant there were to be targeted as one that did not live up to the high standards that it has in the past. Our inspection service is very important in that regard.

Earlier this year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, introduced an AQIS client feedback scheme that included a national framework of experienced staff backed up by a purpose-built computer software program. This takes conventional customer relations a step further in providing a monitoring and a response capability that caters for all users of AQIS. The scheme allows AQIS to respond quickly to particular problems or situations being experienced by individual clients or groups within a particular industry. It is a free service and is assisting Australia's push to export more agricultural products.

AQIS is required to recover 100 per cent of user attributable costs but, because it has been constantly improving the range and quality of services it offers, there have been some good savings, which have led to the need to redistribute the surplus back to the industry, and that is what this bill, of course, is all about. It would make sense if the industry used these savings to improve quality control and the education of producers on the importance of Australia's disease free status and ways and means of producing that.

There is a need to look at the products coming in from overseas and to make them safe for the Australian market without limiting their access. That is an issue that gets plenty of debate in some quarters as well. With the lowering of trade barriers and everything else, governments will at times be accused of using their inspection services and their quarantine services in restricting trade. We should make sure that ours has a professionalism about it and that we have our arguments sound in that regard.

One of those industries that comes within my ambit in Tasmania is the salmon industry. The Canadian salmon industry is endeavouring to push wild salmon into the Australian market. After spending many millions of dollars in establishing our salmon industry, we would certainly want to make sure that whatever was coming into Australia was disease free. That will be something that we will need to watch with great caution. I support the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration (by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Mr Langmore:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the standing committee report called Working with the environment: opportunities for job growth. I found the document an interesting document but some aspects of it seem to me to work in both directions. Some aspects work towards the creation of jobs in the environment but some—and I am not critical of this—seem to be working in the other direction. That is probably the way these things are going to work.

PARA.TAB: In its summary, the report says that the environmental policy should be pursued in an atmosphere of Commonwealth-state cooperation, rather than confrontation, and that there are signs that this cooperation is not always achievable. I think that is true, but I have to say that, from my experience, the blame for it not always being achievable can fall either way. I notice that the report makes a suggestion that it would be a good idea if the Western Australian government were to reconsider its position towards the establishment of the National Environment Protection Council. Members will be aware that we supported very much the establishment of that council but did raise one or two reasons why the Western Australians were unhappy.

It would be wise of the Commonwealth, if it does want that sort of cooperation—and it should happen that we should get that sort of cooperation—not to throw around the threats that it has in the last year or two. I give the example which I have used in this place before; when the Commonwealth could not get its way with the Western Australians on Mabo and the Native Title Bill, through its former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), it threatened to withdraw some of the Landcare funding to Western Australia. If the Commonwealth wants cooperation rather than confrontation, then this is a two-way deal and it should not—
Debate interrupted.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —The second point I wish to make is that nearly the whole first page is filled with recommendations to form interdepartmental committees and agencies and high level groupings and so on. I hope that opportunities for creating jobs in the environment area do not simply come down to opportunities for creating these sorts of jobs alone. I actually agree with the upper end of the prognosis. The committee says that it found there was a potential for employment growth of at least 20,000 jobs within the Australian pollution control industry. Taking a more expansive view of Australia, if Australia could capture only two per cent of the world market, 150,000 jobs could possibly be generated. I would be optimistic about that but I would not be too optimistic if we managed to get too many of these environmental jobs bogged down in committees. In a minute I will come to what I think has been one of the drawbacks under Landcare where that may have become a problem.

PARA.TAB: A considerable amount of space is given in the document to options for a carbon tax. These options are discussed in relation to replacing state payroll tax with a carbon tax or, as described in other places, with an environmental levy. Taxes tend to work against the creation of jobs. As this report had as its main thrust the environment and the creation of jobs, I think that a great deal of care should be given. I admit it says that a lot more evaluation needs to take place and I agree totally.

There is some discussion of greenhouse levels. I think there is an opportunity in this committee to raise the possibility, or at least raise the thought, that we are a long way yet from knowing what sorts of effects the greenhouse gases are going to have on our environment. It behoves us to be extremely careful not to go about any expensive or extremely expensive measures in trying to deal with the problem—a problem which still has a whole lot of questions unanswered.

There is absolutely no doubt that the greenhouse gas emissions are rising enormously and have done. There is no doubt that some of the other gases in their CO(2) equivalents are also doing damage as well as CO(2) itself. As yet—and I just say this in a statistical sense, not in any way in a conclusive sense or in an emotional sense—it does not seem to me that there is conclusive evidence about what is going to happen about the increase in those greenhouse levels. For example, is it true that any warming that is taking place is taking place at night? Is it true that in fact the daytime hours in the last few years have become cooler? Again, I think that science is still out. The answers to these sorts of problems are still out.

While it is tremendously important that this country goes about the business of reducing greenhouse emissions as rapidly as it possibly can, there is no doubt that the government has committed itself in the Rio agreement to arrangements that it probably will not be able to meet. Mind you, I have to say it is no orphan there. Almost every Western—not all, but almost all—OECD government may be in the same boat. I raise it because I think that leads us to another particular subject which one can raise at least in this Main Committee, and that is the matter of sinks.

I raise this to get discussion. I think that the rules that surround the anthropogenic—human-caused—emissions need some looking at. Are we saying that because of the fertilisation effect, the increased CO(2) and its ability to translate into increased growth in the flora sense, we should not be credited in this country with the flora we have? I think it is something worth raising and I raise it in the spirit of debate.

We have not filled our country with people, probably for the very good reason that we do not have the water. We have not done a Singapore. We have not done an East Africa—although those countries would not be included at the present time—and we have not done a China. We have not filled this place up with people, yet the measurement system is on a per capita basis.

It is interesting that our area of influence now extends for 200 nautical miles out to sea. That is, of course, a natural sink in the same way as our land mass is a natural sink. Whether we should or should not be credited with the fact that we have looked after our land mass by not filling it up with human beings, whether we should or should not be accredited with some of the fertilisation effects of that, and whether we should or should not be credited with the sea that we now own are things for Australians to think very seriously about. At the moment, with respect to the rules that have been set, it looks as though we may have to do some things that are rather drastic.

I know there are some provisions under the arrangements for us to take account of geographical differences and there is also a provision that we should not do great harm to the economy of the country. I have not even raised the possibility of taking a more global view by saying that our coal is less polluting than the coal from other countries. I have not raised some of the more obvious difficulties in this business such as what will happen in China and India as they raise their standards of living, and I have not raised the issue of whether the arrangements will harm us economically. I want to make sure that nobody misunderstands our position: we are very keen to drop the greenhouse gas emissions as quickly as is reasonably possible. I think there are some other aspects of this that this parliament needs to debate and think about very seriously.

I notice that there is increased funding for Landcare. We need to look very carefully at this funding because until now most of the Landcare funds have not, in my view, helped the land. The funds have helped those people who are progressing the awareness of Landcare and that has been done very well. There are a lot of people out there now who understand the issue. There are also a lot of people out there who would love to do something about the land they own, but they do not have the resources.

I noticed that there were one or two comments in the recommendations that seemed to say that Commonwealth funding under the national Landcare program should only be directed to state government agencies, subject to an unequivocal commitment by the agencies to use the funding to employ additional staff resources and be subject to regular reporting. I agree with that. As I understand it, the suggestion that some of the states have been stealing the money or not putting the money through to Landcare programs has been made, and that should be stopped.

There is a recommendation that we double the Landcare program. If we are talking about the creation of jobs that recommendation will do two things. Firstly, it will mean caring for the land—with a revegetation program, for instance—which will mean the money will be used for that. Secondly, in the process of that being done in the most efficient way possible, it will create jobs. I draw the attention of members to that particular matter.

I turn to one other matter, not having time to raise more. I noticed that the feral pest program will be increased to at least $10 million a year. Let us just get this down to what has been happening. The Commonwealth itself owns areas full of feral animals—jammed full of them—but does nothing about them. If we are going to use this money properly, firstly we have got to get the science right and the technologies right. But secondly we have got to have some plans. I do not like to use the military term but we must have some strategies as to how this thing is going to happen, and not just throw more dollars over the top of it. It will require people. There are very good people around who could do it. Even today, without too much science, some of these animals could be removed.

I have gone past any of the debate where we start thinking too much about animal liberation. What we have got to think about is the native flora and fauna and how we are going to get rid of these feral animals. I was very pleased to see that the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales had a two-day seminar on this very aspect alone. Those are a few very brief comments on the subject of this report.
Debate (on motion by Mr Chynoweth) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Lindsay)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to make a few comments in relation to greenhouse gases. I first raised this matter back in 1984. At that time it was pooh-poohed and people laughed, saying that nothing would happen. I think people are starting to realise now that the greenhouse effect is actually happening—carbon dioxide and other gases are increasing; the temperature is rising. In about 1985 I made a speech made up of anecdotal bits and pieces that I had ripped out of the newspaper, as I normally do, showing even then massive storms, floods and things like that. I know this is not scientific proof but I feel that these things are increasing around the world and that the greenhouse effect is starting to be evident in the world.

PARA.TAB: What we have got to make certain of is that animals that live in a certain climate have green corridors so that they can shift around and survive. That is something that is going to take a lot of work and will certainly create, as our report says, a lot of green jobs.

I would like to make some comments on various aspects of our report. In the first area we have made a recommendation regarding finance for solar hot water units. In the 1960s I used to work in Darwin, at the time when the federal government built the majority of the housing there. It insisted that solar hot water systems be fitted to all defence houses and things like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And also for national parks, aviation and so on.

—Yes, DCA, et cetera. That government decision forced Australia to set up its own solar heating manufacturing industry. That is the sort of area we can get into once again. Even in Melbourne I have a solar heater in my backyard and I use it for heating my hothouse and swimming pool. I am one of the people who actually use one; however, not many people in Melbourne do it. We could have great savings in Melbourne. Other cities should have it. The Commonwealth government should be giving tax incentives. I know we recommend energy cards and all those sorts of things to try to get people to move more into this area. We are world leaders in solar hot water technology; there is a great market there and we can move in there very quickly. I am quite certain that it will create many thousands of jobs.

PARA.TAB: Another area that I would like to talk about is solar cells. I spoke on this report for a couple of minutes just recently and I spoke about solar cells. To me, that is the way of the future. We are definitely world leaders in solar cell technology. I can foresee that the roofs of our houses will all be solar cells that will power our house and feed our batteries, and then we will just hook into the grid through our computer when the batteries run low or it is a cloudy day or whatever. I can see that actually happening. That sort of technology and that sort of thin film solar cell that is being produced now are a huge leap forward in something that does not burn fossil fuels, does not have any sort of problem with the environment and actually gives advantage to all who use it.

However, I would just like to give an example of one of the problems that is actually apparent right now. In the Australian of some time ago there was a story about a young couple who built their house about 150 kilometres from Brisbane. Liz and Rolf Tennant are the people who built this house, and their power needs are supplied wholly by solar cells and solar energy. They have a local electricity line which is a fair distance away from their particular property. When they moved into this property they spent about $7,000 actually installing the solar technology, the solar power system, solar hot water system, et cetera. For them to connect up to the power grid would have cost $10,500, so they saved probably $3,000. They thought, `We have spent our $7,500, therefore we should not have any power bills from now on.' However, it was not to be. The Queensland equivalent of the SEC, the state power board, has decided to charge them $1,750 for the fact that the power line goes in front of their property. They do not even use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be the Goss government.

—No, I think this is going back to Joh's time. In fact, I am certain it would have been Joh Bjelke-Petersen installing this. He would have had his own people putting up the power poles. Anyway, that is $1,750 to actually have the power lines going past their property. This is the sort of area we should be looking at a lot more closely. Instead of using those power stations in Queensland—I will mention the Victorian power stations later on—emitting all the carbon dioxide and with all the other added problems that go with them, here we have an enterprising couple using environmentally friendly technology and they are still being forced to pay $1,750. That is the sort of area the government should be involved in and we should make certain that the income of that sort of couple should not be affected by this sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: I actually have a water tank at home where I get water off my roof. I let it rain for a while and I have a special little gadget; I pull a handle and fresh water comes in. All the gunk off the roof has been washed off and I have a nice pure water supply. If I stopped the expensive water from the Melbourne Metropolitan Board of Works, or whatever it is called these days, it will charge me rates for just having the water going past, even though I do not use it. These are the sorts of things we should be looking at because all of that extra work that we do in that area creates work for plumbers, solar cell technicians, electricians and so on.

The committee, during its deliberations, visited Alcoa in Portland, Victoria. There is a real problem in Victoria because Alcoa produces a huge amount of aluminium. It is one of the biggest producers of aluminium, and the majority of it goes overseas in ingots. But we are not actually selling aluminium; we are selling electricity, because all that aluminium that is being produced by Alcoa is subsidised by the Victorian taxpayer. It is subsidised to the tune of $198 million per year. This is the Jeffrey Kennett government. It is forcing Victorians to subsidise this huge multinational to the tune, as I said, of $198 million a year.

If we say it is $200 million a year and there are 800 people working at Alcoa in Portland, with my skills in maths it is quite easy to work it out this way. We subsidise it for $200 million a year. That is, each one of those people working there is subsidised $250,000 per year. I would not mind getting a job for $250,000. We could close down this aluminium plant in Portland, pay those people $200,000 a year and we would still be making a profit. That will not happen, of course, but what the Victorian government should do is get stuck into Alcoa, not give it this subsidy.

I know the Treasurer there has been making some noises about this but the government really should take Alcoa on. All these multinational companies are doing is taking cheap electricity, polluting our atmosphere, and shipping it somewhere else. It is important that we point out these things. The people who work in this plant are being subsidised to the tune of $250,000 per year. It is important to have those people working there. Their product and their wages go back into the community but it is also important to look at the economics of this sort of development which in some areas is being pushed fairly hard.

Another submission to the committee was on the idea of making a pilot tidal plant in the Kimberleys. This was mentioned by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). I have heard about this idea for many years. I have actually seen a bay there where the tide is a waterfall going in and a waterfall going out. This happens every day. There is a huge potential for power to be generated there just going to waste.

The Kimberleys are a long way away. There is not much there that could use electricity. If we put lines down, it would just be wasted. However, there is another process called electrolysis where people could use the electricity to convert sea water into hydrogen gas and pipe this gas to Perth, NSW, Victoria and Queensland. This is the Rex Connor idea coming back but I think it could work. Hydrogen is a gas that, once burnt, is non-pollutant. It is virtually inexhaustible up in the Kimberleys because we are always going to have tides and they will always be generating electricity.

We have said that there should be some sort of pilot study there and I think we should make certain that that comes about. That is another area in the future which could create a lot of jobs, could improve the environment and could make it certain that we have unlimited power in a very cheap form. Hydrogen gas could be used not only for heating, for driving gas generators and turbines for electricity in the major cities, but also for cars and things like that. I can envisage a time when we will pull up in our garage and hook up to the gas line and charge the commuter car up overnight.

There is another interesting statistic about the green area which I think gets lost. People forget about it. A survey was taken of taxpayers' priorities. It was on what taxpayers want most of all for their dollar. The area where they want the most money spent is the environment. If we have a look at it, they want less money spent on national defence. They want less money spent on unemployment. They want less money spent on general government administration. They want more on roads. They want more on sport and they want more on education. They want more on retraining and age pensions but the one that comes out the highest where they want the most is the environment. They want a 115 per cent change—an increase in spending on the environment. That is what this particular report is all about. It is important that the recommendations in this report are looked at closely. They give a guide to what will happen in the future and I believe they can create many thousands of jobs.

I was disappointed to hear what happened in one area in Victoria. Some time ago money was going to be put into a wind farm at Kilcunda, in south Gippsland. A firm was already allocated to build it. However, Jeffrey Kennett decided to scotch that. He said that we have got abundant electricity from Latrobe Valley—which we have—and he did not think it was necessary to put in one of these wind generators. To me that was an absolute disgrace. The amount of power that actually comes out of brown coal was referred to recently in a Four Corners program. For 100 per cent of brown coal put in, what is wasted is about 60 per cent. We get only a 40 per cent return from the brown coal that goes in. Mr Kennett and his people are promoting this and therefore not only using up a valuable resource but also ruining our environment.

One has only to go to the Latrobe Valley to find that the people who still have jobs and work there—Mr Kennett sacked about 10,000 of them, or some other huge number—have to live under very harsh conditions because of the pollution. I know the state government is taking steps to improve it. However, it has sold off part of our electricity generating area. I am quite certain that the power companies that have bought it will not be interested in looking after the environment; they are interested only in getting a quick buck and returning it to their American shareholders. To me, the removal by Jeffrey Kennett of the wind farm program was wrong. The program should be reinstated. The technology is there to get a return from wind power, which should be promoted as much as possible.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations International Conference on Population and Development

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Dr Theophanous:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am responding to the joint statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) on the International Conference on Population and Development recently held in Cairo. They spoke about the consensus reached at the conference and the real part Australia played in the process.

PARA.TAB: I had the privilege of attending the conference, which was a major world event, on behalf of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). My colleagues have informed us that the conference has produced a global program of action on population and development. For the first time there is international agreement that countries need to make positive investments to improve the social and economic conditions of their populations, and especially the conditions of women. We have heard that there are specific strategies for empowering women to participate equally with men in the development process. These strategies include actions to improve women's health.

Australia is at the forefront in developments in women's health and we have already put in place many of the strategies which were recommended by the conference. Australia, for example, is one of the few countries to have a national women's health policy. In 1989, following consultations in one way or another with over one million women, the government launched the national women's health policy. The goals of the policy are to improve the health and wellbeing of all women in Australia, with a focus on those most at risk, and to encourage the health system to be more responsive to the needs of women.

I am pleased to report that sexual and reproductive health, a major action area in the Cairo program of action, has already been identified as one of the priority health issues for women in Australia. Thus Australia's national women's health program has funded over 360 projects throughout the nation, providing innovative women's health services, information and training, including health promotion, counselling and support services to victims of sexual assault and violence, ethnic liaison services and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander services.

The Cairo program of action put forward strategies for addressing the specific needs of indigenous people. I am pleased to be able to report that over 10 per cent of projects funded under the national women's health program are targeted to indigenous women. I praise the efforts of our diplomats and our negotiators who managed to ensure that that issue of indigenous people remained as part of the general agenda in Cairo.

Empowerment of women and freedom of choice in relation to health services were two important themes in Cairo. One area in which women have demanded greater choice is that of birthing services. The government responded to this by establishing the alternative birthing services program in 1989. This program recognises that pregnancy and childbirth are, in the majority of cases, normal life events requiring minimal intervention. As a result of this program, some hospitals have significantly modified their birthing practices, resulting in fewer interventions and more control by women themselves over the birthing process. It is to be hoped that this trend will continue and that for all healthy women the alternative birthing service will become the norm.

The Cairo program of action put forward a wide range of strategies to address women's morbidity and mortality. In Australia breast cancer and cancer of the cervix are major health issues for women. In 1991 the government introduced screening programs aimed at reducing mortality from breast and cervical cancers. The national program for the early detection of breast cancer, which formally commenced in July 1991, is establishing a network of accredited screening and assessment services across the country. There are currently 28 screening and assessment services operated from 87 units. Seventeen of these are mobile. It is expected that the program will be fully operational by 1996-97, when it aims to screen 1.1 million women in the target age group of 50 to 69 every two years. The government also aims to ensure that the treatment and care of women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer are the very best quality by world standards.

In 1991 the Commonwealth government introduced the organised approach to preventing cancer of the cervix. Future directions in this program can be summed up in two words—participation and quality. Only 50 to 60 per cent of Australian women in the target age group of 18 to 69 years of age are adequately screened. It is crucial to increase these numbers when we consider that without the program there would be an estimated 1,700 new cases of cervical cancer every year. There will be more announcements about this program later this year and early next year.

The Cairo program of action placed a strong emphasis on making family planning services widely available. In Australia the government has funded a national family planning program for over 15 years. It has established a network of sexual and reproductive health services, including family planning information, education, training, counselling and clinical activities throughout Australia.

Most members would have seen media reports about the abortion issue in the Cairo conference. The program of action states clearly and explicitly that in no case should abortion be promoted as a method of family planning. This is consistent with Australia's policy on family planning. Australia believes that satisfying the demand for family planning services will reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies and reduce the need for women to resort to abortion.

The Cairo document also stresses the rights of choice and non-coercion in family planning programs. In Australia this is translated not only into the service provided but also in the very choice of the service providers—state and territory family planning associations, general practitioners, hospital postnatal wards, natural family planning centres and community and women's health centres.

Australia fully supports the stance of the program of action resulting from the International Conference on Population and Development which recognises abortion as an important health issue for women, particularly the disastrous health impact of unsafe abortions. Of particular concern is the fact that in developing countries up to 500 women die each day from the complications of unsafe abortions and many more are seriously injured. Recognising there can be compelling health reasons for women to seek to terminate a pregnancy, the government has therefore provided financial support within the health system to allow access to voluntary legal and safe abortion. This is consistent with the Cairo program of action which states that where abortion is not against the law countries should ensure that such abortion is safe.

The program of action specifically directs countries actively to discourage the harmful practice of female genital mutilation. The extent to which this occurs in Australia is not yet known but there are increasing numbers of migrants from countries where it is practised. In June this year, the Family Law Council published a report on female genital mutilation. The government is currently considering legislative options as well as sensitively targeted education with relevant communities.

Australia has already given high priority to many of the goals of the program of action and the targets are more than met but some challenges still remain. While Australia meets international standards, it needs to continue to address the needs of particular groups, such as indigenous people and those from non-English speaking backgrounds, to enable them to enjoy the same high standards of health care as the majority of Australians.

The International Conference on Population and Development had a single overarching focus that transcended religious and cultural differences. It was the focus to achieve social justice for all humanity. In the speech that I gave at the parliamentary level conference, I pointed this out. Notwithstanding the enormous cultural diversity that we have, it is still possible for all human beings to come together on certain fundamental principles of human rights and certain fundamental principles of social justice.

There was some initial conflict at the conference in relation to what would be agreed and what would not be agreed. There were some divisions, as was bound to be the case with more than 160 countries. A lot of the media publicity that occurred prior to the conference and even during the conference proved not to be accurate when it came to the final situation of resolving the issues. An overwhelming number of those nations agreed to the document. Even when some people objected to specific clauses—and there were very few countries that did that—they cooperated. For example, His Holiness the Pope had some reservations, as one would expect, in relation to the abortion issue and other aspects concerning reproductive health. Notwithstanding that, it was important that the Vatican and all the Catholic countries and an overwhelming number of the Muslim countries agreed to the document.

So we have had a very interesting and very important lesson taught us in Cairo. That is, there are a lot of people who are prepared to emphasise the differences between nations and the differences between cultures as if they are a negative, as if they prevent the possibility of people coming together to agree on basic principles of social justice. This conference proved that people can have agreement on basic principles of social justice, notwithstanding the huge cultural diversity and ethnic diversity that exists in the world.

It was an historic conference and I was very proud to be there, to represent Australia and to be able to participate in the events. I might say that Australia was thanked on a number of occasions and one that I want to mention involved the Pacific island countries. The minister was unable to be present at the reception and I hosted the reception for the Pacific island countries on his behalf. What was very important was that the representatives from those countries thanked Australia because they were only able to participate in the conference because of a significant contribution by Australia towards the cost of getting their delegations there. This was a very important contribution that Australia made because, as we know, population issues and issues concerning birth control and issues concerning women's health are all significant matters in these nations. The people there were very appreciative of that.

Another thing I want to mention is a very important reception we had when the Australian delegation invited representatives from other delegations to the Australian Embassy in Cairo. We had a very good turnout. The organiser of the conference, the wonderful lady Nafis Sadik, who is the United Nations representative on population issues, did us the honour of attending the reception, which I had the honour of hosting. She had organised what I think was the largest UN conference held so far—it was certainly just as large, and some say it was larger, than Rio. She spent a lot of time with our diplomats and representatives, and I think that there was a great appreciation of the role that Australia played from the beginning in all of the negotiations leading up to the conference and in helping to achieve a very good result.

The noble principles of social justice are increasingly being heard throughout the world. The reason is, I believe, that social justice is a critical element in the very definition of basic human rights. When it came to the point, we had to decide in the charter whether we were going to actually implement a number of specific issues that related directly to the international declaration of human rights or whether we were going to walk away from that declaration. It was a positive conference—I think that fact has not been sufficiently emphasised—the determinations of which reinforced the declaration.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: External Funding

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the CSIRO exceeded the external funding target of 30 per cent set by the Government; if so, to what extent will this affect the CSIRO's funding contribution to the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre.

(2) Will the Government ensure full, adequate and continuous funding of the centre if the CSIRO reduces, withdraws or fails to renew funding when existing arrangements cease; if so, through what arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) CSIRO has exceeded its external earnings funding target of 30 per cent in 1992-93 and 1993-94 (reaching 33 per cent in 1993-94).

There is no connection between external funds received by CSIRO and funds made available annually to the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre. These are made available through the CSIRO Division of Water Resources and the amount provided each year was originally allocated on the basis of the costs of five staff seconded to the Centre.
Since aggregation of the Centre within the Co-operative Research Centre for Freshwater Ecology, CSIRO's contribution has continued at the same level but with less specificity in application.
As indicated in my response to Question No. 1293 earlier this year, CSIRO intends to maintain its current level of funding ($326,000 in 1993-94) throughout the current triennium.

(2) Decisions concerning continued funding for the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre after 1996-97 will be made by the CSIRO in the broader context of its funding arrangements for the next triennium.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bandiana and Puckapunyal Barracks: Solar Insulation

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Department of Defence engage companies to construct (a) six buildings at Bandiana Barracks, Vic., and (b) battalion headquarters and senior non-commissioned ranks accommodation wings at Puckapunyal Barracks, Vic.; if so, in each case, (i) what company was engaged, (ii) what were the Department's requirements for sunlight screening and insulation of external windows, (iii) what product was used for sunlight screening and insulation on the windows, skylights, doors and glazed atriums, (iv) which company was responsible for the installation and supply of the insulation materials, (v) what were the exact specifications of (A) Australian Construction Services or (B) the Department for the solar reflective and insulation requirements of the doors, windows and other glass areas and (vi) were the specifications altered (A) before, (B) during or (C) after the tendering and installation process; if so how.
(2) Did the Department claim that $100 000 was saved by using a material other than Solar-Mesh for the insulation on the external glass of the buildings; if so, on what basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

Bandiana

The functional design brief for each building stated the general requirement for sunlight screening , insulation and energy conservation as:

`A cool and comfortable work environment is required throughout. Passive environmental control measures with adequate cross ventilation should be used to achieve these standards wherever feasible. Consideration is to be given to conserving fuel and/or power used for heating, cooling and lighting by:
a. siting buildings to make maximum use of prevailing winds and the sun for temperature control and lighting;
b. using insulating materials and weather proof seals;
c. using solar energy where considered cost effective; and
d. using under the floor heating systems.'

Australian Construction Services undertook the design and documentation of the facilities and developed the functional design briefs into design specifications. With the exception of one building, `Solar Mesh' was specified as either a shading mesh screen or insect screen as a proprietary item to be fitted to each facility. Extracts from the specifications are detailed in the following table. The product was intended for use on north and west facing windows to reduce solar gain. Changes to the specified use of `Solar Mesh' were as follows:
a. RTC Electronics Wing. `Solar Mesh' installed to windows as specified; however, installation to

ANSWER.PARA: skylights deleted because of doubts regarding effectiveness in that particular application.

PARA.TAB: b. RTC HQ and Corps Training Wing. An alternative product, `Kool Shade', was selected and installed post-construction tender award.
c. Central Instruction Facility. `Solar Mesh' installed as specified.
d. Area Physical Fitness Centre. Requirement deleted after tender.
e. RAAOC Centre Q Store. Contract not proceeded with.
f. Training Warehouse. `Solar-Mesh' installed as specified.
g. Puckapunyal Logistic Battalion HQ. `Solar-Mesh' was not specified. Sun shades included on construction drawings.

h. SNCO Accommodation. `Solar-Mesh' was specified as an insect screen to openable windows. Sun shades were detailed on drawings. Insect screens were supplied as part of the window set. Requirement for `Solar-Mesh' was deleted during construction period.
Defence purchasing policy is based on open and effective competition and inclusion of `Solar-Mesh' in the specifications did not constitute an obligation on Defence's part to use the product.

An alternative product was used on one building although the cost was essentially the same as the Solar-Mesh product.

For Defence facilities projects, tenderers are required to submit conforming bids but can also nominate changes that may achieve better value for money for the Commonwealth. The process of design review and material evaluation continues throughout the contract period.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to growing community concern at the extent of telemarketing in Australia.
(2) What steps are (a) the Government or (b) Telecom taking to preserve the right of privacy of telephone subscribers who resent the unsolicited intrusion represented by telemarketing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government is aware of concern expressed about the privacy implications of telecommunications, including telemarketing in Australia.

(2)(a) Following consideration of the AUSTEL Privacy Report, and consultation with the Attorney-General and the Privacy Commissioner, on 16 August 1994, I announced my decision to request AUSTEL to establish a Privacy Advisory Committee to examine telecommunications privacy issues. I identified telemarketing, protection of customer personal information and caller identification as issues that the committee should report on as matters of priority. The committee has been established and includes representatives of the carriers, the Privacy Commissioner, the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO), and a consumer representative nominated by the Minister for Consumer Affairs.
A Working Group has also been established by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to consider and report on the broader issue of Direct Marketing, which also includes telemarketing.

In recognition of the ongoing importance of telecommunications privacy, the recently announced review of the telecommunications policy and regulatory arrangements for post-1997 will also be considering the issue.
(2)(b) Telecom has provided the following advice:
Telstra is a member of the recently established AUSTEL Privacy Advisory Committee. As a member of that committee Telstra will contribute to the resolution of consumer concerns about telemarketing.
Telstra has developed a telemarketing Code of Practice for its own telemarketing activities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industry, Science and Technology: Stress Counselling

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did the Department or any agency for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility spend any sum on stress counselling services for Commonwealth employees or their families in 1993-94.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Yes, the details for the Department and agencies are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Department of Industry, Science and Technology

PARA.TAB: The Department has a contract with a private service provider, EASACT Australia Pty Ltd (formerly the Employee Assistance Service), which provides counselling for staff and their families to help staff address stressful situations at work and in their personal lives.

The ACS employs staff counsellors as well as providing off site employee assistance programs. In addition to providing direct counselling services, counsellors are involved in a range of issues in the training area. Stress will be a factor in many cases dealt with by the counsellors. It is estimated that around 60% of cases involve work related stress.
The ADA has not spent any specific amounts on stress counselling services. However, services of this nature are available to staff under the DIST contract with EASACT Australia Pty Ltd.

AIPO has a contract with EASACT Australia Pty Ltd for the provision, interalia, of stress counselling as part of its overall service to staff and immediate families. During 1993/94 stress problems accounted for 9% of consultations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS)

PARA.TAB: AIMS has an employee assistance program in place for all counselling purposes. The Institute subscribes to an organisation called Interlock. Employees make use of the counselling services as required.

The AMCS is included as part of the Department in the contract that DIST has with EASACT Australia Pty Ltd. This service is funded wholly by the Department. No funds have been expended by the AMCS on stress counselling services for staff or their families.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation

PARA.TAB: ANSTO has engaged, on a sessional basis a qualified psychologist to provide psychological counselling services to its staff and where appropriate (eg bereavement), their families. This person is engaged for one day per fortnight. A Medical Officer is also employed on a full time basis at ANSTO. Staff are also provided with appropriate stress counselling by the Medical Officer as required.
CSIRO provides personal counselling services for staff and members of their families. All of these services include stress counselling provided by consultant clinical psychologists.
In addition to this, individual business units (Divisions) within CSIRO spend varying amounts on stress management sessions for groups of managers and staff.
EFIC has not knowingly spent any sum on stress counselling services. However, EFIC retains a counselling service for its employees which may cover, among other services, stress counselling.

To ensure that patient/client confidentiality is maintained, the terms and conditions of the counselling service agreement do not permit the identification of the persons, or the reason for counselling—only the number of hours of counselling provided and the number of specialist referrals.
The NSC has not spent any sum on stress counselling services for NSC employees or their families.

ANSWER.PARA: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority

PARA.TAB: The TCFDA has not spent any specific amounts on stress counselling services. However, services of this nature are available to staff under the DIST contract with EASACT Australia Pty Ltd.
